797468_14_ITEM7_P188_S0	Environmental Costs Occidental s environmental costs, some of which include estimates, are presented below for each segment for each of the years ended December 31:
797468_14_ITEM7_P189_S0	Operating expenses are incurred on a continual basis.
797468_14_ITEM7_P190_S0	Capital expenditures relate to longer-lived improvements in properties currently operated by Occidental.
797468_14_ITEM7_P190_S1	Remediation expenses relate to existing conditions from past operations.
797468_14_ITEM7_P190_S2	Occidental presently estimates capital expenditures for environmental compliance of approximately $130 million for 2014.
797468_14_ITEM7_P191_S0	FOREIGN INVESTMENTS Many of Occidental s assets are located outside North America.
797468_14_ITEM7_P191_S1	At December 31, 2013 , the carrying value of Occidental s assets in countries outside North America aggregated approximately $13.7 billion, or approximately 20 percent of Occidental s total assets at that date.
797468_14_ITEM7_P191_S2	Of such assets, approximately $11.9 billion are located in the Middle East/North Africa and approximately $1.7 billion are located in Latin America.
797468_14_ITEM7_P191_S3	For the year ended December 31, 2013 , net sales outside North America totaled $8.2 billion, or approximately 34 percent of total net sales.
797468_14_ITEM7_P192_S0	CRITICAL ACCOUNTING POLICIES AND ESTIMATES The process of preparing financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles requires Occidental's management to make informed estimates and judgments regarding certain items and transactions.
797468_14_ITEM7_P192_S1	Changes in facts and circumstances or discovery of new information may result in revised estimates and judgments, and actual results may differ from these estimates upon settlement but generally not by material amounts.
797468_14_ITEM7_P192_S2	There has been no material change to Occidental's critical accounting policies over the past three years.
797468_14_ITEM7_P192_S3	The selection and development of these policies and estimates have been discussed with the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors.
797468_14_ITEM7_P192_S4	Occidental considers the following to be its most critical accounting policies and estimates that involve management's judgment.
797468_14_ITEM7_P193_S0	The carrying value of Occidental s PP E represents the cost incurred to acquire or develop the asset, including any asset retirement obligations and capitalized interest, net of accumulated depreciation, depletion and amortization and any impairment charges.
797468_14_ITEM7_P193_S1	For assets acquired, PP E cost is based on fair values at the acquisition date.
797468_14_ITEM7_P194_S0	Asset retirement obligations and interest costs incurred in connection with qualifying capital expenditures are capitalized and amortized over the lives of the related assets.
797468_14_ITEM7_P195_S0	Occidental uses the successful efforts method to account for its oil and gas properties.
797468_14_ITEM7_P195_S1	Under this method, Occidental capitalizes costs of acquiring properties, costs of drilling successful exploration wells and development costs.
797468_14_ITEM7_P195_S2	The costs of exploratory wells are initially capitalized pending a determination of whether proved reserves have been found.
797468_14_ITEM7_P195_S3	If proved reserves have been found, the costs of exploratory wells remain capitalized.
797468_14_ITEM7_P195_S4	Otherwise, Occidental charges the costs of the related wells to expense.
797468_14_ITEM7_P196_S0	In some cases, a determination of proved reserves cannot be made at the completion of drilling, requiring additional testing and evaluation of the wells.
797468_14_ITEM7_P196_S1	Occidental generally expenses the costs of such exploratory wells if a determination of proved reserves has not been made within a 12-month period after drilling is complete.
797468_14_ITEM7_P196_S2	Occidental expenses annual lease rentals, the costs of injectants used in production and geological, geophysical and seismic costs as incurred.
797468_14_ITEM7_P197_S0	Occidental determines depreciation and depletion of oil and gas producing properties by the unit-of-production method.
797468_14_ITEM7_P197_S1	It amortizes acquisition costs over total proved reserves and capitalized development and successful exploration costs over proved developed reserves.
797468_14_ITEM7_P198_S0	Proved oil and gas reserves are those quantities of oil and gas which, by analysis of geoscience and engineering data, can be estimated with reasonable certainty to be economically producible from a given date forward, from known reservoirs, and under existing economic conditions, operating methods, and government regulations prior to the time at which contracts providing the right to operate expire, unless evidence indicates that renewal is reasonably certain, regardless of whether deterministic or probabilistic methods are used for the estimation.
797468_14_ITEM7_P198_S1	Occidental has no proved oil and gas reserves for which the determination of economic producibility is subject to the completion of major additional capital expenditures.
797468_14_ITEM7_P199_S0	Several factors could change Occidental s proved oil and gas reserves.
797468_14_ITEM7_P199_S1	For example, Occidental receives a share of production from PSCs to recover its costs and generally an additional share for profit.
797468_14_ITEM7_P199_S2	Occidental s share of production and reserves from these contracts decreases when product prices rise and increases when prices decline.
797468_14_ITEM7_P199_S3	Overall, Occidental s net economic benefit from these contracts is greater at higher product prices.
797468_14_ITEM7_P199_S4	In other cases, particularly with long-lived properties, lower product prices may lead to a situation where production of a portion of proved reserves becomes uneconomical.
797468_14_ITEM7_P199_S5	For such properties, higher product prices typically result in additional reserves becoming economical.
797468_14_ITEM7_P200_S0	future production and development costs is also subject to change partially due to factors beyond Occidental's control, such as energy costs and inflation or deflation of oil field service costs.
797468_14_ITEM7_P200_S1	These factors, in turn, could lead to changes in the quantity of proved reserves.
797468_14_ITEM7_P200_S2	Additional factors that could result in a change of proved reserves include production decline rates and operating performance differing from those estimated when the proved reserves were initially recorded.
797468_14_ITEM7_P200_S3	In 2013 , revisions of previous estimates provided a net 4 million BOE increase in proved reserves, which amounted to less than 1 percent of Occidental's total reserves as of December 31, 2013 .
797468_14_ITEM7_P200_S4	Additionally, Occidental performs impairment tests with respect to its proved properties when product prices decline other than temporarily, reserve estimates change significantly, other significant events occur or management's plans change with respect to these properties in a manner that may impact Occidental's ability to realize the recorded asset amounts.
797468_14_ITEM7_P200_S5	Impairment tests incorporate a number of assumptions involving expectations of undiscounted future cash flows, which can change significantly over time.
797468_14_ITEM7_P200_S6	These assumptions include estimates of future product prices, which Occidental bases on forward price curves and, when applicable, contractual prices, estimates of oil and gas reserves and estimates of future expected operating and development costs.
797468_14_ITEM7_P200_S7	Any impairment loss would be calculated as the excess of the asset's net book value over its estimated fair value.
797468_14_ITEM7_P200_S8	The most significant ongoing financial statement effect from a change in Occidental's oil and gas reserves or impairment of its proved properties would be to the DD A rate.
797468_14_ITEM7_P200_S9	For example, a 5-percent increase or decrease in the amount of oil and gas reserves would change the DD A rate by approximately $0.85 per barrel, which would increase or decrease pre-tax income by approximately $240 million annually at current production rates.
797468_14_ITEM7_P200_S10	The change in the DD A rate over the past three years due to revisions of previous proved reserve estimates has been immaterial.
797468_14_ITEM7_P201_S0	A portion of the carrying value of Occidental s oil and gas properties is attributable to unproved properties.
797468_14_ITEM7_P201_S1	At December 31, 2013 , the net capitalized costs attributable to unproved properties were $3.6 billion.
797468_14_ITEM7_P201_S2	The unproved amounts are not subject to DD A until they are classified as proved properties.
797468_14_ITEM7_P201_S3	As exploration and development work progresses, if reserves on these properties are proved, capitalized costs attributable to the properties become subject to DD A.
797468_14_ITEM7_P201_S4	If the exploration and development work were to be unsuccessful, or management decided not to pursue development of these properties as a result of lower commodity prices, higher development and operating costs, contractual conditions or other factors, the capitalized costs of the related properties would be expensed.
797468_14_ITEM7_P201_S5	The timing of any writedowns of these unproved properties, if warranted, depends upon management's plans, the nature, timing and extent of future exploration and development activities and their results.
797468_14_ITEM7_P201_S6	Occidental believes its current plans and exploration and development efforts will allow it to realize its unproved property balance.
797468_14_ITEM7_P202_S0	During its annual capital planning process in the fourth quarter of 2013, management determined that it would not pursue development of certain of its non-producing domestic oil and gas acreage based on product prices, availability of transportation capacity to market the products and regulatory and environmental considerations.
797468_14_ITEM7_P202_S1	As a result, Occidental recorded pre-tax impairment charges of $0.6 billion for the acreage.
797468_14_ITEM7_P203_S0	The profitability of certain of Occidental's Middle East/North Africa operations, and in turn its ability to realize its recorded asset values, is dependent upon the success of future development plans or normalization of operations in some locations.
797468_14_ITEM7_P203_S1	Further, the strategic review Occidental is currently undertaking may result in the sale of certain assets, some of which may result in losses.
797468_14_ITEM7_P203_S2	Such losses, if any, will be recorded when a definitive sale decision is made.
797468_14_ITEM7_P204_S0	Chemical Assets Occidental's chemical assets are depreciated using either the unit-of-production or the straight-line method, based upon the estimated useful lives of the facilities.
797468_14_ITEM7_P204_S1	The estimated useful lives of Occidental s chemical assets, which range from three years to 50 years, are also used for impairment tests.
797468_14_ITEM7_P204_S2	The estimated useful lives for the chemical facilities are based on the assumption that Occidental will provide an appropriate level of annual expenditures to ensure productive capacity is sustained.
797468_14_ITEM7_P204_S3	Such expenditures consist of ongoing routine repairs and maintenance, as well as planned major maintenance activities (PMMA).
797468_14_ITEM7_P204_S4	Ongoing routine repairs and maintenance expenditures are expensed as incurred.
797468_14_ITEM7_P204_S5	PMMA costs are capitalized and amortized over the period until the next planned overhaul.
797468_14_ITEM7_P204_S6	Additionally, Occidental incurs capital expenditures that extend the remaining useful lives of existing assets, increase their capacity or operating efficiency beyond the original specification or add value through modification for a different use.
797468_14_ITEM7_P204_S7	These capital expenditures are not considered in the initial determination of the useful lives of these assets at the time they are placed into service.
797468_14_ITEM7_P204_S8	The resulting revision, if any, of the asset s estimated useful life is measured and accounted for prospectively.
797468_14_ITEM7_P204_S9	Without these continued expenditures, the useful lives of these assets could decrease significantly.
797468_14_ITEM7_P204_S10	Other factors that could change the estimated useful lives of Occidental s chemical assets include sustained higher or lower product prices, which are particularly affected by both domestic and foreign competition, demand, feedstock costs, energy prices, environmental regulations and technological changes.
797468_14_ITEM7_P205_S0	Occidental performs impairment tests on its chemical assets whenever events or changes in circumstances lead to a reduction in the estimated useful lives or estimated future cash flows that would indicate that the carrying amount may not be recoverable, or when management s plans change with respect to those assets.
797468_14_ITEM7_P205_S1	Any impairment loss would be calculated as the excess of the asset's net book value over its estimated fair value.
797468_14_ITEM7_P206_S0	Occidental's net PP E for the chemical segment is approximately $2.8 billion and its depreciation expense for 2014 is expected to be approximately $325 million.
797468_14_ITEM7_P206_S1	The most significant financial statement impact of a decrease in the estimated useful lives of Occidental's chemical plants would be on depreciation expense.
797468_14_ITEM7_P206_S2	For example, a reduction in the remaining useful lives of one year would increase depreciation and reduce pre-tax earnings by approximately $45 million per year.
797468_14_ITEM7_P207_S0	Midstream, Marketing and Other Assets Derivatives are carried at fair value and on a net basis when a legal right of offset exists with the same counterparty.
797468_14_ITEM7_P208_S0	Occidental applies hedge accounting when transactions meet specified criteria for cash-flow hedge treatment and management elects and documents such treatment.
797468_14_ITEM7_P208_S1	Otherwise, any fair value gains or losses are recognized in earnings in the current period.
797468_14_ITEM7_P209_S0	For cash-flow hedges, the gain or loss on the effective portion of the derivative is reported as a component of other comprehensive income (OCI) with an offsetting adjustment to the basis of the item being hedged.
797468_14_ITEM7_P209_S1	Realized gains or losses from cash-flow hedges, and any ineffective portion, are recorded as a component of net sales in the consolidated statements of income.
797468_14_ITEM7_P210_S0	Ineffectiveness is primarily created by a lack of correlation between the hedged item and the hedging instrument due to location, quality, grade or changes in the expected quantity of the hedged item.
797468_14_ITEM7_P211_S0	Gains and losses from derivative instruments are reported net in the consolidated statements of income.
797468_14_ITEM7_P211_S1	There were no fair value hedges as of and during the year ended December 31, 2013 .
797468_14_ITEM7_P212_S0	A hedge is regarded as highly effective such that it qualifies for hedge accounting if, at inception and throughout its life, it is expected that changes in the fair value or cash flows of the hedged item will be offset by 80 to 125 percent of the changes in the fair value or cash flows, respectively, of the hedging instrument.
797468_14_ITEM7_P213_S0	In the case of hedging a forecast transaction, the transaction must be probable and must present an exposure to variations in cash flows that could ultimately affect reported net income or loss.
797468_14_ITEM7_P213_S1	Occidental discontinues hedge accounting when it determines that a derivative has ceased to be highly effective as a hedge; when the hedged item matures or is sold or repaid; or when a forecast transaction is no longer deemed probable.
797468_14_ITEM7_P214_S0	Occidental's midstream and marketing PP E is depreciated over the estimated useful lives of the assets, using either the unit-of-production or straight-line method.
797468_14_ITEM7_P215_S0	Occidental performs impairment tests on its midstream and marketing assets whenever events or changes in circumstances lead to a reduction in the estimated useful lives or estimated future cash flows that would indicate that the carrying amount may not be recoverable, or when management s plans change with respect to those assets.
797468_14_ITEM7_P215_S1	Any impairment loss would be calculated as the excess of the asset's net book value over its estimated fair value.
797468_14_ITEM7_P216_S0	Fair Value Measurements Occidental has categorized its assets and liabilities that are measured at fair value in a three-level fair value hierarchy, based on the inputs to the valuation techniques: Level 1 using quoted prices in active markets for the assets or liabilities; Level 2 using observable inputs other than quoted prices for the assets or liabilities; and Level 3 using unobservable inputs.
797468_14_ITEM7_P216_S1	Transfers between levels, if any, are recognized at the end of each reporting period.
797468_14_ITEM7_P217_S0	Fair Values - Recurring Occidental primarily applies the market approach for recurring fair value measurements, maximizes its use of observable inputs and minimizes its use of unobservable inputs.
797468_14_ITEM7_P217_S1	Occidental utilizes the mid-point between bid and ask prices for valuing the majority of its assets and liabilities measured and reported at fair value.
797468_14_ITEM7_P217_S2	In addition to using market data, Occidental makes assumptions in valuing its assets and liabilities, including assumptions about the risks inherent in the inputs to the valuation technique.
797468_14_ITEM7_P217_S3	For assets and liabilities carried at fair value, Occidental measures fair value using the following methods:
797468_14_ITEM7_P218_S0	Commodity derivatives Occidental values exchange-cleared commodity derivatives using closing prices provided by the exchange as of the balance sheet date.
797468_14_ITEM7_P218_S1	These derivatives are classified as Level 1.
797468_14_ITEM7_P219_S0	Over-the-Counter (OTC) bilateral financial commodity contracts, foreign exchange contracts, options and physical commodity forward purchase and sale contracts are generally valued using quotations provided by brokers or industry-standard models that consider various inputs, including quoted forward prices for commodities, time value, volatility factors, credit risk and current market and contractual prices for the underlying instruments, as well as other relevant economic measures.
797468_14_ITEM7_P219_S1	Substantially all of these inputs are observable in the marketplace throughout the full term of the instrument, and can be derived from observable data or are supported by observable prices at which transactions are executed in the marketplace.
797468_14_ITEM7_P219_S2	Occidental generally classifies these measurements as Level 2.
797468_14_ITEM7_P220_S0	Embedded commodity derivatives Occidental values embedded commodity derivatives based on a market approach that considers various assumptions, including quoted forward commodity prices and market yield curves.
797468_14_ITEM7_P220_S1	The assumptions used include inputs that are observable and unobservable in the marketplace, and the fair value is designated as Level 3 within the valuation hierarchy.
797468_14_ITEM7_P221_S0	Occidental generally uses an income approach to measure fair value when there is not a market-observable price for an identical or similar asset or liability.
797468_14_ITEM7_P221_S1	This approach utilizes management's judgments regarding expectations of projected cash flows, and discounts those cash flows using a risk-adjusted discount rate.
797468_14_ITEM7_P222_S0	Environmental Liabilities and Expenditures Environmental expenditures that relate to current operations are expensed or capitalized as appropriate.
797468_14_ITEM7_P222_S1	Occidental records environmental reserves and related charges and expenses for estimated remediation costs that relate to existing conditions from past operations when environmental remediation efforts are probable and the costs can be reasonably estimated.
797468_14_ITEM7_P222_S2	In determining the reserves and the range of reasonably possible additional losses, Occidental refers to currently available information, including relevant past experience, remedial objectives, available technologies, applicable laws and regulations and cost-sharing arrangements.
797468_14_ITEM7_P222_S3	Occidental bases environmental reserves on management s estimate of the most likely cost to be incurred, using the most cost-effective technology reasonably expected to achieve the remedial objective.
797468_14_ITEM7_P222_S4	Occidental periodically reviews reserves and adjusts them as new information becomes available.
797468_14_ITEM7_P222_S5	Occidental records environmental reserves on a discounted basis when it deems the aggregate amount and timing of cash payments to be reliably determinable at the time the reserves are established.
797468_14_ITEM7_P222_S6	The reserve methodology with respect to discounting for a specific site is not modified once it is established.
797468_14_ITEM7_P223_S0	The amount of discounted environmental reserves is insignificant.
797468_14_ITEM7_P224_S0	Occidental generally records reimbursements or recoveries of environmental remediation costs in income when received, or when receipt of recovery is highly probable.
797468_14_ITEM7_P224_S1	As of December 31, 2013 , 2012 and 2011 , Occidental did not have any accruals for reimbursements or recoveries.
797468_14_ITEM7_P225_S0	Many factors could affect Occidental s future remediation costs and result in adjustments to its environmental reserves and range of reasonably possible additional losses.
797468_14_ITEM7_P225_S1	The most significant are: (1) cost estimates for remedial activities may be inaccurate; (2) the length of time, type or amount of remediation necessary to achieve the remedial objective may change due to factors such as site conditions, the ability to identify and control contaminant sources or the discovery of additional contamination; (3) a regulatory agency may ultimately reject or modify Occidental s proposed remedial plan; (4) improved or alternative remediation technologies may change remediation costs; (5) laws and regulations may change remediation requirements or affect cost sharing or allocation of liability; and (6) changes in allocation or cost-sharing arrangements may occur.
797468_14_ITEM7_P226_S0	Certain sites involve multiple parties with various cost-sharing arrangements, which fall into the following three categories: (1) environmental proceedings that result in a negotiated or prescribed allocation of remediation costs among Occidental and other alleged potentially responsible parties; (2) oil and gas ventures in which each participant pays its proportionate share of remediation costs reflecting its working interest; or (3) contractual arrangements, typically relating to purchases and sales of properties, in which the parties to the transaction agree to methods of allocating remediation costs.
797468_14_ITEM7_P227_S0	consequences to Occidental of their failure to participate when estimating Occidental's ultimate share of liability.
797468_14_ITEM7_P227_S1	Occidental records reserves at its expected net cost of remedial activities and, based on these factors, believes that it will not be required to assume a share of liability of such other potentially responsible parties in an amount materially above amounts reserved.
797468_14_ITEM7_P227_S2	In addition to the costs of investigations and cleanup measures, which often take in excess of 10 years at NPL sites, Occidental's reserves include management's estimates of the costs to operate and maintain remedial systems.
797468_14_ITEM7_P227_S3	If remedial systems are modified over time in response to significant changes in site-specific data, laws, regulations, technologies or engineering estimates, Occidental reviews and adjusts its reserves accordingly.
797468_14_ITEM7_P228_S0	If Occidental were to adjust the environmental reserve balance based on the factors described above, the amount of the increase or decrease would be recognized in earnings.
797468_14_ITEM7_P228_S1	For example, if the reserve balance were reduced by 10 percent, Occidental would record a pre-tax gain of $33 million.
797468_14_ITEM7_P228_S2	If the reserve balance were increased by 10 percent, Occidental would record an additional remediation expense of $33 million.
797468_14_ITEM7_P229_S0	Other Loss Contingencies Occidental is involved, in the normal course of business, in lawsuits, claims and other legal proceedings and audits.
797468_14_ITEM7_P229_S1	Occidental accrues reserves for these matters when it is probable that a liability has been incurred and the liability can be reasonably estimated.
797468_14_ITEM7_P229_S2	In addition, Occidental discloses, in aggregate, its exposure to loss in excess of the amount recorded on the balance sheet for these matters if it is reasonably possible that an additional material loss may be incurred.
797468_14_ITEM7_P229_S3	Occidental reviews its loss contingencies on an ongoing basis.
797468_14_ITEM7_P229_S4	Loss contingencies are based on judgments made by management with respect to the likely outcome of these matters and are adjusted as appropriate.
797468_14_ITEM7_P229_S5	Management s judgments could change based on new information, changes in, or interpretations of, laws or regulations, changes in management s plans or intentions, opinions regarding the outcome of legal proceedings, or other factors.
797468_14_ITEM7_P229_S6	See "Lawsuits, Claims and Other Contingencies" for additional information.
797468_14_ITEM7_P230_S0	SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING AND DISCLOSURE CHANGES Listed below are significant recently adopted accounting and disclosure changes.
797468_14_ITEM7_P231_S0	Offsetting Assets and Liabilities Beginning in the quarter ended March 31, 2013, Occidental adopted new disclosure requirements relating to its derivatives in accordance with rules issued by the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) in December 2011 and January 2013.
797468_14_ITEM7_P231_S1	These new rules require tabular disclosures of the outstanding derivatives' gross and net fair values, now including those derivatives that are subject to a master netting or similar arrangement and qualify for net presentation, whether or not offset in the consolidated balance sheet.
797468_14_ITEM7_P232_S0	Reclassification from Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income Beginning in the quarter ended March 31, 2013, Occidental adopted new disclosure requirements for reporting amounts reclassified out of each component of accumulated other comprehensive income into the income statement in accordance with rules issued by the FASB in February 2013.
797468_14_ITEM7_P233_S0	These new disclosures were not material to Occidental's financial statements.
797468_14_ITEM7_P234_S0	DERIVATIVE ACTIVITIES AND MARKET RISK Commodity Price Risk General Occidental s results are sensitive to fluctuations in oil, NGL and natural gas prices.
797468_14_ITEM7_P234_S1	Price changes at current global prices and levels of production affect Occidental s pre-tax annual income by approximately $150 million for a $1 per barrel change in oil prices and $30 million for a $1 per barrel change in NGL prices.
797468_14_ITEM7_P234_S2	If domestic natural gas prices varied by $0.50 per Mcf, it would have an estimated annual effect on Occidental's pre-tax income of approximately $100 million.
797468_14_ITEM7_P234_S3	These price-change sensitivities include the impact of PSC and similar contract volume changes on income.
797468_14_ITEM7_P234_S4	If production levels change in the future, the sensitivity of Occidental s results to prices also will change.
797468_14_ITEM7_P234_S5	The marketing and trading results are sensitive to price changes of oil, gas and, to a lesser degree, other commodities.
797468_14_ITEM7_P234_S6	These sensitivities are additionally dependent on marketing and trading volumes and cannot be predicted reliably.
797468_14_ITEM7_P234_S7	Occidental s results are also sensitive to fluctuations in chemical prices.
797468_14_ITEM7_P234_S8	A variation in chlorine and caustic soda prices of $10 per ton would have a pre-tax annual effect on income of approximately $10 million and $30 million, respectively.
797468_14_ITEM7_P234_S9	A variation in PVC prices of $0.01 per lb. would have a pre-tax annual effect on income of approximately $25 million.
797468_14_ITEM7_P235_S0	Historically, over time, product price changes have tracked raw material and feedstock product price changes, somewhat mitigating the effect of price changes on margins.
797468_14_ITEM7_P236_S0	According to IHS Chemical, December 2013 average contract prices were: chlorine $245 per ton; caustic soda $583 per ton; and PVC $0.61 per lb.
797468_14_ITEM7_P237_S0	Occidental uses derivative instruments, including a combination of short-term futures, forwards, options and swaps, to obtain the average prices for the relevant production month and to improve realized prices for oil and gas.
797468_14_ITEM7_P237_S1	Occidental only occasionally hedges its oil and gas production, and, when it does so, the volumes are usually insignificant.
797468_14_ITEM7_P237_S2	Additionally, Occidental s Phibro trading unit engages in trading activities using derivatives for the purpose of generating profits mainly from market price changes of commodities.
797468_14_ITEM7_P238_S0	Risk Management Occidental conducts its risk management activities for marketing and trading activities under the controls and governance of its risk control policy.
797468_14_ITEM7_P238_S1	The controls under this policy are implemented and enforced by a Risk Management group which manages risk by providing an independent and separate evaluation and check.
797468_14_ITEM7_P238_S2	Members of the Risk Management group report to the Corporate Vice President and Treasurer.
797468_14_ITEM7_P238_S3	The President and Chief Executive Officer, and Executive Vice President of Operations also oversee these controls.
797468_14_ITEM7_P238_S4	Controls for these activities include limits on value at risk, limits on credit, limits on total notional trade value, segregation of duties, delegation of authority, daily price verifications, daily reporting to senior management of positions together with various risk measures and a number of other policy and procedural controls.
797468_14_ITEM7_P238_S5	Additionally, these operations maintain highly liquid positions, as a result of which the market risk typically can be neutralized on short notice.
797468_14_ITEM7_P239_S0	Fair Value of Marketing and Trading Derivative Contracts Occidental carries derivative contracts it enters into in connection with its marketing and trading activities at fair value.
797468_14_ITEM7_P239_S1	Fair values for these contracts are derived principally from Level 1 and Level 2 sources.
797468_14_ITEM7_P239_S2	The following table shows the fair value of Occidental's derivatives (excluding collateral), segregated by maturity periods and by methodology of fair value estimation:
797468_14_ITEM7_P240_S0	Note : Includes cash-flow hedges further discussed below.
797468_14_ITEM7_P241_S0	Cash-Flow Hedges Occidental entered into financial swap agreements in November 2012 for the sale of a portion of its natural gas production in California.
797468_14_ITEM7_P241_S1	These swap agreements hedge 50 million cubic feet of natural gas per day beginning in January 2013 through March 2014 and qualify as cash-flow hedges.
797468_14_ITEM7_P241_S2	The weighted-average strike price of these swaps is $4.30.
797468_14_ITEM7_P242_S0	Occidental s marketing and trading operations store natural gas purchased from third parties at Occidental s North American leased storage facilities.
797468_14_ITEM7_P242_S1	Derivative instruments are used to fix margins on the future sales of the stored volumes through March 31, 2014.
797468_14_ITEM7_P243_S0	As of December 31, 2013 and 2012 , Occidental had approximately 11 billion cubic feet and 20 billion cubic feet of natural gas held in storage, respectively.
797468_14_ITEM7_P243_S1	As of December 31, 2013 and 2012 , Occidental had cash-flow hedges for the forecast sale, to be settled by physical delivery, of approximately 13 billion cubic feet and 20 billion cubic feet of this stored natural gas, respectively.
797468_14_ITEM7_P244_S0	As of December 31, 2013 , the total fair value of cash-flow hedges, which was a net liability of $4 million, was included in the total fair value table in "Fair Value of Marketing and Trading Derivative Contracts" above.
797468_14_ITEM7_P245_S0	Quantitative Information Occidental uses value at risk to estimate the potential effects of changes in fair values of commodity-based and foreign currency derivatives and commodity contracts used in marketing and trading activities.
797468_14_ITEM7_P245_S1	This method determines the maximum potential negative short-term change in fair value with at least a 95-percent level of confidence.
797468_14_ITEM7_P245_S2	Additionally, Occidental uses trading limits, including, among others, limits on total notional trade value, and maintains liquid positions as a result of which market risk typically can be neutralized on short notice.
797468_14_ITEM7_P245_S3	As a result of these controls, Occidental has determined that the market risk of the marketing and trading activities is not reasonably likely to have a material adverse effect on its operations.
797468_14_ITEM7_P246_S0	Interest Rate Risk General Occidental's exposure to changes in interest rates is not expected to be material and relates to its variable-rate long-term debt obligations.
797468_14_ITEM7_P246_S1	As of December 31, 2013 , variable-rate debt constituted approximately 1 percent of Occidental's total debt.

797468_14_ITEM7_P249_S0	Credit Risk Occidental's credit risk relates primarily to its derivative financial instruments and trade receivables.
797468_14_ITEM7_P250_S0	Occidental s contracts are spread among a large number of counterparties.
797468_14_ITEM7_P251_S0	Creditworthiness is reviewed before doing business with a new counterparty and on an ongoing basis.
797468_14_ITEM7_P251_S1	Credit exposure for each customer is monitored for outstanding balances, current activity, and forward mark-to-market exposure.
797468_14_ITEM7_P252_S0	A substantial portion of Occidental s derivative transaction volume is executed through exchange-traded contracts, which are subject to nominal credit risk as a significant portion of these transactions is settled on a daily margin basis with select clearinghouses and brokers.
797468_14_ITEM7_P252_S1	Occidental executes the rest of its derivative transactions in the OTC market.
797468_14_ITEM7_P253_S0	Occidental is subject to counterparty credit risk to the extent the counterparty to the derivatives is unable to meet its settlement commitments.
797468_14_ITEM7_P253_S1	Occidental manages this credit risk by selecting counterparties that it believes to be financially strong, by spreading the credit risk among many such counterparties, by entering into master netting arrangements with the counterparties and by requiring collateral, as appropriate.
797468_14_ITEM7_P253_S2	Occidental actively monitors the creditworthiness of each counterparty and records valuation adjustments to reflect counterparty risk, if necessary.
797468_14_ITEM7_P253_S3	Certain of Occidental's OTC derivative instruments contain credit-risk-contingent features, primarily tied to credit ratings for Occidental or its counterparties, which may affect the amount of collateral that each would need to post.
797468_14_ITEM7_P253_S4	As of December 31, 2013 and 2012 , Occidental had a net liability of $8 million and $34 million, respectively, which are net of collateral posted of $23 million and $64 million, respectively.
797468_14_ITEM7_P253_S5	Occidental believes that if it had received a one-notch reduction in its credit ratings, it would not have resulted in a material change in its collateral-posting requirements as of December 31, 2013 and 2012 .
797468_14_ITEM7_P253_S6	As of December 31, 2013 , the substantial majority of the credit exposures was with investment grade counterparties.
797468_14_ITEM7_P253_S7	Occidental believes its exposure to credit-related losses at December 31, 2013 was not material and losses associated with credit risk have been insignificant for all years presented.
797468_14_ITEM7_P254_S0	Foreign Currency Risk Occidental s foreign operations have limited currency risk.
797468_14_ITEM7_P254_S1	Occidental manages its exposure primarily by balancing monetary assets and liabilities and limiting cash positions in foreign currencies to levels necessary for operating purposes.
797468_14_ITEM7_P254_S2	A vast majority of international oil sales are denominated in United States dollars.
797468_14_ITEM7_P254_S3	Additionally, all of Occidental s consolidated foreign oil and gas subsidiaries have the United States dollar as the functional currency.
797468_14_ITEM7_P254_S4	As of December 31, 2013 , the fair value of foreign currency derivatives used in the trading operations was immaterial.
797468_14_ITEM7_P255_S0	The effect of exchange rates on transactions in foreign currencies is included in periodic income.

797468_14_ITEM8_P0_S0	The management of Occidental Petroleum Corporation and its subsidiaries (Occidental) is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.
797468_14_ITEM8_P0_S1	Occidental s system of internal control over financial reporting is designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of consolidated financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
797468_14_ITEM8_P0_S2	Occidental s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that: (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of Occidental s assets; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that Occidental s receipts and expenditures are being made only in accordance with authorizations of Occidental s management and directors; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of Occidental s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
797468_14_ITEM8_P0_S3	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
797468_14_ITEM8_P0_S4	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.

797468_14_ITEM8_P5_S0	A company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
797468_14_ITEM8_P5_S1	A company's internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that: (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
797468_14_ITEM8_P5_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
797468_14_ITEM8_P5_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.

797468_14_ITEM8_P12_S0	NATURE OF OPERATIONS In this report, "Occidental" means Occidental Petroleum Corporation, a Delaware corporation (OPC), or OPC and one or more entities in which it owns a controlling interest (subsidiaries).
797468_14_ITEM8_P13_S0	Occidental conducts its operations through various subsidiaries and affiliates.
797468_14_ITEM8_P13_S1	Occidental's principal businesses consist of the oil and gas, chemical and midstream, marketing and other (midstream and marketing) segments.
797468_14_ITEM8_P14_S0	The oil and gas segment explores for, develops and produces oil and condensate, natural gas liquids (NGL) and natural gas.
797468_14_ITEM8_P14_S1	The chemical segment (OxyChem) mainly manufactures and markets basic chemicals and vinyls.
797468_14_ITEM8_P15_S0	The midstream and marketing segment gathers, processes, transports, stores, purchases and markets oil, condensate, NGLs, natural gas, carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) and power.
797468_14_ITEM8_P15_S1	It also trades around its assets, including transportation and storage capacity, and trades oil, NGLs, gas and other commodities.
797468_14_ITEM8_P15_S2	Additionally, the midstream and marketing segment invests in entities that conduct similar activities.
797468_14_ITEM8_P16_S0	The consolidated financial statements have been prepared in conformity with United States generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) and include the accounts of OPC, its subsidiaries and its undivided interests in oil and gas exploration and production ventures.
797468_14_ITEM8_P17_S0	Occidental accounts for its share of oil and gas exploration and production ventures, in which it has a direct working interest, by reporting its proportionate share of assets, liabilities, revenues, costs and cash flows within the relevant lines on the balance sheets, income statements and cash flow statements.
797468_14_ITEM8_P17_S1	Certain financial statements, notes and supplementary data for prior years have been reclassified to conform to the 2013 presentation.
797468_14_ITEM8_P18_S0	INVESTMENTS IN UNCONSOLIDATED ENTITIES Occidental s percentage interest in the underlying net assets of affiliates as to which it exercises significant influence without having a controlling interest (excluding oil and gas ventures in which Occidental holds an undivided interest) are accounted for under the equity method.
797468_14_ITEM8_P18_S1	Occidental reviews equity-method investments for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that an other-than-temporary decline in value may have occurred.
797468_14_ITEM8_P18_S2	The amount of impairment, if any, is based on quoted market prices, when available, or other valuation techniques, including discounted cash flows.
797468_14_ITEM8_P19_S0	REVENUE RECOGNITION Revenue is recognized from oil and gas production when title has passed to the customer, which occurs when the product is shipped.
797468_14_ITEM8_P19_S1	In international locations where oil is shipped by tanker, title passes when the tanker is loaded or product is received by the customer, depending on the shipping terms.
797468_14_ITEM8_P19_S2	This process occasionally causes a difference between actual production in a reporting period and sales volumes that have been recognized as revenue.
797468_14_ITEM8_P20_S0	Revenue from chemical product sales is recognized when the product is shipped and title has passed to the customer.
797468_14_ITEM8_P21_S0	Certain incentive programs may provide for payments or credits to be made to customers based on the volume of product purchased over a defined period.
797468_14_ITEM8_P21_S1	Total customer incentive payments over a given period are estimated and recorded as a reduction to revenue ratably over the contract period.
797468_14_ITEM8_P21_S2	Such estimates are evaluated and revised as warranted.
797468_14_ITEM8_P22_S0	Revenue from marketing and trading activities is recognized on net settled transactions upon completion of contract terms and, for physical deliveries, upon title transfer.
797468_14_ITEM8_P22_S1	For unsettled transactions, contracts are recorded at fair value and changes in fair value are reflected in net sales.
797468_14_ITEM8_P23_S0	Revenue from all marketing and trading activities is reported on a net basis.
797468_14_ITEM8_P23_S1	Occidental records revenue net of any taxes, such as sales taxes, that are assessed by governmental authorities on Occidental's customers.
797468_14_ITEM8_P24_S0	RISKS AND UNCERTAINTIES The process of preparing consolidated financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires Occidental's management to make informed estimates and judgments regarding certain types of financial statement balances and disclosures.
797468_14_ITEM8_P24_S1	Such estimates primarily relate to unsettled transactions and events as of the date of the consolidated financial statements and judgments on expected outcomes as well as the materiality of transactions and balances.
797468_14_ITEM8_P24_S2	Changes in facts and circumstances or discovery of new information relating to such transactions and events may result in revised estimates and judgments and actual results may differ from estimates upon settlement.
797468_14_ITEM8_P24_S3	Management believes that these estimates and judgments provide a reasonable basis for the fair presentation of Occidental s financial statements.
797468_14_ITEM8_P25_S0	Occidental establishes a valuation allowance against net operating losses and other deferred tax assets to the extent it believes the future benefit from these assets will not be realized in the statutory carryforward periods.
797468_14_ITEM8_P25_S1	Realization of deferred tax assets, including any net operating loss carryforwards, is dependent upon Occidental generating sufficient future taxable income and reversal of temporary differences in jurisdictions where such assets originate.
797468_14_ITEM8_P26_S0	The accompanying consolidated financial statements include assets of approximately $13.7 billion as of December 31, 2013 , and net sales of approximately $8.2 billion for the year ended December 31, 2013 , relating to Occidental s operations in countries outside North America.
797468_14_ITEM8_P27_S0	Occidental operates some of its oil and gas business in countries that occasionally have experienced political instability, nationalizations, corruption, armed conflict, terrorism, insurgency, civil unrest, security problems, labor unrest, OPEC production restrictions, equipment import restrictions and sanctions, all of which increase Occidental's risk of loss or delayed or restricted production or may result in other adverse consequences.
797468_14_ITEM8_P27_S1	Occidental attempts to conduct its affairs so as to mitigate its exposure to such risks and would seek compensation in the event of nationalization.
797468_14_ITEM8_P28_S0	Because Occidental s major products are commodities, significant changes in the prices of oil and gas and chemical products may have a significant impact on Occidental s results of operations.
797468_14_ITEM8_P28_S1	Also, see "Property, Plant and Equipment" below.
797468_14_ITEM8_P29_S0	CASH AND CASH EQUIVALENTS Cash equivalents are short-term, highly liquid investments that are readily convertible to cash.
797468_14_ITEM8_P29_S1	Cash equivalents were approximately $2.9 billion and $1.0 billion at December 31, 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
797468_14_ITEM8_P30_S0	INVESTMENTS Available-for-sale securities are recorded at fair value with any unrealized gains or losses included in accumulated other comprehensive income/loss (AOCI).
797468_14_ITEM8_P30_S1	Trading securities are recorded at fair value with unrealized and realized gains or losses included in net sales.
797468_14_ITEM8_P31_S0	INVENTORIES Materials and supplies are valued at weighted-average cost and are reviewed periodically for obsolescence.
797468_14_ITEM8_P31_S1	Oil, NGL and natural gas inventories are valued at the lower of cost or market.
797468_14_ITEM8_P31_S2	For the chemical segment, Occidental's finished goods inventories are valued at the lower of cost or market.
797468_14_ITEM8_P31_S3	For most of its domestic inventories, other than materials and supplies, the chemical segment uses the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method as it better matches current costs and current revenue.
797468_14_ITEM8_P31_S4	For other countries, Occidental uses the first-in, first-out method (if the costs of goods are specifically identifiable) or the average-cost method (if the costs of goods are not specifically identifiable).
797468_14_ITEM8_P32_S0	The carrying value of Occidental s property, plant and equipment (PP E) represents the cost incurred to acquire or develop the asset, including any asset retirement obligations and capitalized interest, net of accumulated depreciation, depletion and amortization (DD A) and any impairment charges.
797468_14_ITEM8_P32_S1	For assets acquired, PP E cost is based on fair values at the acquisition date.
797468_14_ITEM8_P33_S0	Asset retirement obligations and interest costs incurred in connection with qualifying capital expenditures are capitalized and amortized over the lives of the related assets.
797468_14_ITEM8_P34_S0	Occidental uses the successful efforts method to account for its oil and gas properties.
797468_14_ITEM8_P34_S1	Under this method, Occidental capitalizes costs of acquiring properties, costs of drilling successful exploration wells and development costs.
797468_14_ITEM8_P34_S2	The costs of exploratory wells are initially capitalized pending a determination of whether proved reserves have been found.
797468_14_ITEM8_P34_S3	If proved reserves have been found, the costs of exploratory wells remain capitalized.
797468_14_ITEM8_P34_S4	Otherwise, Occidental charges the costs of the related wells to expense.
797468_14_ITEM8_P35_S0	In some cases, a determination of proved reserves cannot be made at the completion of drilling, requiring additional testing and evaluation of the wells.
797468_14_ITEM8_P35_S1	Occidental generally expenses the costs of such exploratory wells if a determination of proved reserves has not been made within a 12 -month period after drilling is complete.
797468_14_ITEM8_P35_S2	The following table summarizes the activity of capitalized exploratory well costs for continuing operations for the years ended December 31:
797468_14_ITEM8_P36_S0	Occidental expenses annual lease rentals, the costs of injectants used in production and geological, geophysical and seismic costs as incurred.
797468_14_ITEM8_P37_S0	Occidental determines depreciation and depletion of oil and gas producing properties by the unit-of-production method.
797468_14_ITEM8_P37_S1	It amortizes acquisition costs over total proved reserves, and capitalized development and successful exploration costs over proved developed reserves.
797468_14_ITEM8_P38_S0	Proved oil and gas reserves are those quantities of oil and gas which, by analysis of geoscience and engineering data, can be estimated with reasonable certainty to be economically producible from a given date forward, from known reservoirs, and under existing economic conditions, operating methods, and government regulations prior to the time at which contracts providing the right to operate expire, unless evidence indicates that renewal is reasonably certain, regardless of whether deterministic or probabilistic methods are used for the estimation.
797468_14_ITEM8_P38_S1	Occidental has no proved oil and gas reserves for which the determination of economic producibility is subject to the completion of major additional capital expenditures.
797468_14_ITEM8_P38_S2	Additionally, Occidental performs impairment tests with respect to its proved properties when product prices decline other than temporarily, reserve estimates change significantly, other significant events occur or management's plans change with respect to these properties in a manner that may impact Occidental's ability to realize the recorded asset amounts.
797468_14_ITEM8_P38_S3	Impairment tests incorporate a number of assumptions involving expectations of undiscounted future cash flows, which can change significantly over time.
797468_14_ITEM8_P38_S4	These assumptions include estimates of future product prices, which Occidental bases on forward price curves and, when applicable, contractual prices, estimates of oil and gas reserves and estimates of future expected operating and development costs.
797468_14_ITEM8_P38_S5	Any impairment loss would be calculated as the excess of the asset's net book value over its estimated fair value.
797468_14_ITEM8_P39_S0	A portion of the carrying value of Occidental s oil and gas properties is attributable to unproved properties.
797468_14_ITEM8_P39_S1	At December 31, 2013 , the net capitalized costs attributable to unproved properties were $3.6 billion.
797468_14_ITEM8_P39_S2	The unproved amounts are not subject to DD A until they are classified as proved properties.
797468_14_ITEM8_P39_S3	As exploration and development work progresses, if reserves on these properties are proved, capitalized costs attributable to the properties become subject to DD A.
797468_14_ITEM8_P39_S4	If the exploration and development work were to be unsuccessful, or management decided not to pursue development of these properties as a result of lower commodity prices, higher development and operating costs, contractual conditions or other factors, the capitalized costs of the related properties would be expensed.
797468_14_ITEM8_P39_S5	The timing of any writedowns of these unproved properties, if warranted, depends upon management's plans, the nature, timing and extent of future exploration and development activities and their results.
797468_14_ITEM8_P39_S6	Occidental believes its current plans and exploration and development efforts will allow it to realize its unproved property balance.
797468_14_ITEM8_P40_S0	Chemical Occidental s chemical assets are depreciated using either the unit-of-production or the straight-line method, based upon the estimated useful lives of the facilities.
797468_14_ITEM8_P40_S1	The estimated useful lives of Occidental s chemical assets, which range from three years to 50 years, are also used for impairment tests.
797468_14_ITEM8_P40_S2	The estimated useful lives for the chemical facilities are based on the assumption that Occidental will provide an appropriate level of annual expenditures to ensure productive capacity is sustained.
797468_14_ITEM8_P40_S3	Such expenditures consist of ongoing routine repairs and maintenance, as well as planned major maintenance activities (PMMA).
797468_14_ITEM8_P40_S4	Ongoing routine repairs and maintenance expenditures are expensed as incurred.
797468_14_ITEM8_P40_S5	PMMA costs are capitalized and amortized over the period until the next planned overhaul.
797468_14_ITEM8_P40_S6	Additionally, Occidental incurs capital expenditures that extend the remaining useful lives of existing assets, increase their capacity or operating efficiency beyond the original specification or add value through modification for a different use.
797468_14_ITEM8_P40_S7	These capital expenditures are not considered in the initial determination of the useful lives of these assets at the time they are placed into service.
797468_14_ITEM8_P40_S8	The resulting revision, if any, of the asset s estimated useful life is measured and accounted for prospectively.
797468_14_ITEM8_P40_S9	Without these continued expenditures, the useful lives of these assets could decrease significantly.
797468_14_ITEM8_P40_S10	Other factors that could change the estimated useful lives of Occidental s chemical assets include sustained higher or lower product prices, which are particularly affected by both domestic and foreign competition, demand, feedstock costs, energy prices, environmental regulations and technological changes.
797468_14_ITEM8_P41_S0	Occidental performs impairment tests on its chemical assets whenever events or changes in circumstances lead to a reduction in the estimated useful lives or estimated future cash flows that would indicate that the carrying amount may not be recoverable, or when management s plans change with respect to those assets.
797468_14_ITEM8_P41_S1	Any impairment loss would be calculated as the excess of the asset s net book value over its estimated fair value.
797468_14_ITEM8_P42_S0	Midstream and Marketing Occidental s midstream and marketing PP E is depreciated over the estimated useful lives of the assets, using either the unit-of-production or straight-line method.
797468_14_ITEM8_P42_S1	Occidental performs impairment tests on its midstream and marketing assets whenever events or changes in circumstances lead to a reduction in the estimated useful lives or estimated future cash flows that would indicate that the carrying amount may not be recoverable, or when management s plans change with respect to those assets.
797468_14_ITEM8_P42_S2	Any impairment loss would be calculated as the excess of the asset s net book value over its estimated fair value.
797468_14_ITEM8_P43_S0	FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS Occidental has categorized its assets and liabilities that are measured at fair value in a three-level fair value hierarchy, based on the inputs to the valuation techniques: Level 1 using quoted prices in active markets for the assets or liabilities; Level 2 using observable inputs other than quoted prices for the assets or liabilities; and Level 3 using unobservable inputs.
797468_14_ITEM8_P43_S1	Transfers between levels, if any, are reported at the end of each reporting period.
797468_14_ITEM8_P44_S0	Fair Values - Recurring Occidental primarily applies the market approach for recurring fair value measurements, maximizes its use of observable inputs and minimizes its use of unobservable inputs.
797468_14_ITEM8_P44_S1	Occidental utilizes the mid-point between bid and ask prices for valuing the majority of its assets and liabilities measured and reported at fair value.
797468_14_ITEM8_P44_S2	In addition to using market data, Occidental makes assumptions in valuing its assets and liabilities, including assumptions about the risks inherent in the inputs to the valuation technique.
797468_14_ITEM8_P44_S3	For assets and liabilities carried at fair value, Occidental measures fair value using the following methods:
797468_14_ITEM8_P45_S0	Commodity derivatives Occidental values exchange-cleared commodity derivatives using closing prices provided by the exchange as of the balance sheet date.
797468_14_ITEM8_P45_S1	These derivatives are classified as Level 1.
797468_14_ITEM8_P46_S0	Over-the-Counter (OTC) bilateral financial commodity contracts, foreign exchange contracts, options and physical commodity forward purchase and sale contracts are generally valued using quotations provided by brokers or industry-standard models that consider various inputs, including quoted forward prices for commodities, time value, volatility factors, credit risk and current market and contractual prices for the underlying instruments, as well as other relevant economic measures.
797468_14_ITEM8_P46_S1	Substantially all of these inputs are observable in the marketplace throughout the full term of the instrument and can be derived from observable data or are supported by observable prices at which transactions are executed in the marketplace.
797468_14_ITEM8_P46_S2	Occidental classifies these measurements as Level 2.
797468_14_ITEM8_P47_S0	Embedded commodity derivatives Occidental values embedded commodity derivatives based on a market approach that considers various assumptions, including quoted forward commodity prices and market yield curves.
797468_14_ITEM8_P47_S1	The assumptions used include inputs that are observable and unobservable in the marketplace, and the fair value is designated as Level 3 within the valuation hierarchy.
797468_14_ITEM8_P48_S0	Occidental generally uses an income approach to measure fair value when there is not a market-observable price for an identical or similar asset or liability.
797468_14_ITEM8_P48_S1	This approach utilizes management's judgments regarding expectations of projected cash flows, and discounts those cash flows using a risk-adjusted discount rate.
797468_14_ITEM8_P49_S0	ACCRUED LIABILITIES CURRENT Accrued liabilities include accrued payroll, commissions and related expenses of $459 million and $385 million at December 31, 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
797468_14_ITEM8_P50_S0	ENVIRONMENTAL LIABILITIES AND EXPENDITURES Environmental expenditures that relate to current operations are expensed or capitalized as appropriate.
797468_14_ITEM8_P50_S1	Occidental records environmental reserves and related charges and expenses for estimated remediation costs that relate to existing conditions from past operations when environmental remediation efforts are probable and the costs can be reasonably estimated.
797468_14_ITEM8_P50_S2	In determining the reserves and the range of reasonably possible additional losses, Occidental refers to currently available information, including relevant past experience, remedial objectives, available technologies, applicable laws and regulations and cost-sharing arrangements.
797468_14_ITEM8_P50_S3	Occidental bases environmental reserves on management s estimate of the most likely cost to be incurred, using the most cost-effective technology reasonably expected to achieve the remedial objective.
797468_14_ITEM8_P50_S4	Occidental periodically reviews reserves and adjusts them as new information becomes available.
797468_14_ITEM8_P50_S5	Occidental records environmental reserves on a discounted basis when it deems the aggregate amount and timing of cash payments to be reliably determinable at the time the reserves are established.
797468_14_ITEM8_P50_S6	The reserve methodology with respect to discounting for a specific site is not modified once it is established.
797468_14_ITEM8_P51_S0	The amount of discounted environmental reserves is insignificant.
797468_14_ITEM8_P52_S0	Occidental generally records reimbursements or recoveries of environmental remediation costs in income when received, or when receipt of recovery is highly probable.
797468_14_ITEM8_P52_S1	As of December 31, 2013 , 2012 and 2011 , Occidental did not have any accruals for reimbursements or recoveries.
797468_14_ITEM8_P53_S0	Many factors could affect Occidental s future remediation costs and result in adjustments to its environmental reserves and range of reasonably possible additional losses.
797468_14_ITEM8_P53_S1	The most significant are: (1) cost estimates for remedial activities may be inaccurate; (2) the length of time, type or amount of remediation necessary to achieve the remedial objective may change due to factors such as site conditions, the ability to identify and control contaminant sources or the discovery of additional contamination; (3) a regulatory agency may ultimately reject or modify Occidental s proposed remedial plan; (4) improved or alternative remediation technologies may change remediation costs; (5) laws and regulations may change remediation requirements or affect cost sharing or allocation of liability; and (6) changes in allocation or cost-sharing arrangements may occur.
797468_14_ITEM8_P54_S0	Certain sites involve multiple parties with various cost-sharing arrangements, which fall into the following three categories: (1) environmental proceedings that result in a negotiated or prescribed allocation of remediation costs among Occidental and other alleged potentially responsible parties; (2) oil and gas ventures in which each participant pays its proportionate share of remediation costs reflecting its working interest; or (3) contractual arrangements, typically relating to purchases and sales of properties, in which the parties to the transaction agree to methods of allocating remediation costs.
797468_14_ITEM8_P54_S1	In these circumstances, Occidental evaluates the financial viability of the other parties with whom it is alleged to be jointly liable, the degree of their commitment to participate and the consequences to Occidental of their failure to participate when estimating Occidental's ultimate share of liability.
797468_14_ITEM8_P54_S2	Occidental records reserves at its expected net cost of remedial activities and, based on these factors, believes that it will not be required to assume a share of liability of such other potentially responsible parties in an amount materially above amounts reserved.
797468_14_ITEM8_P55_S0	In addition to the costs of investigations and cleanup measures, which often take in excess of 10 years at Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) National Priorities List (NPL) sites, Occidental's reserves include management's estimates of the costs to operate and maintain remedial systems.
797468_14_ITEM8_P55_S1	If remedial systems are modified over time in response to significant changes in site-specific data, laws, regulations, technologies or engineering estimates, Occidental reviews and adjusts its reserves accordingly.
797468_14_ITEM8_P56_S0	ASSET RETIREMENT OBLIGATIONS Occidental recognizes the fair value of asset retirement obligations in the period in which a determination is made that a legal obligation exists to dismantle an asset and reclaim or remediate the property at the end of its useful life and the cost of the obligation can be reasonably estimated.
797468_14_ITEM8_P56_S1	The liability amounts are based on future retirement cost estimates and incorporate many assumptions such as time to abandonment, technological changes, future inflation rates and the risk-adjusted discount rate.
797468_14_ITEM8_P56_S2	When the liability is initially recorded, Occidental capitalizes the cost by increasing the related PP E balances.
797468_14_ITEM8_P56_S3	If the estimated future cost of the asset retirement obligation changes, Occidental records an adjustment to both the asset retirement obligation and PP E. Over time, the liability is increased and expense is recognized for accretion, and the capitalized cost is depreciated over the useful life of the asset.
797468_14_ITEM8_P57_S0	At a certain number of its facilities, Occidental has identified conditional asset retirement obligations that are related mainly to plant decommissioning.
797468_14_ITEM8_P57_S1	Occidental does not know or cannot estimate when it may settle these obligations.
797468_14_ITEM8_P57_S2	Therefore, Occidental cannot reasonably estimate the fair value of these liabilities.
797468_14_ITEM8_P57_S3	Occidental will recognize these conditional asset retirement obligations in the periods in which sufficient information becomes available to reasonably estimate their fair values.
797468_14_ITEM8_P58_S0	The following table summarizes the activity of the asset retirement obligation, of which $1,283 million and $1,212 million is included in deferred credits and other liabilities - other, with the remaining current portion in accrued liabilities at December 31, 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
797468_14_ITEM8_P59_S0	DERIVATIVE INSTRUMENTS Derivatives are carried at fair value and on a net basis when a legal right of offset exists with the same counterparty.
797468_14_ITEM8_P60_S0	Occidental applies hedge accounting when transactions meet specified criteria for cash-flow hedge treatment and management elects and documents such treatment.
797468_14_ITEM8_P60_S1	Otherwise, any fair value gains or losses are recognized in earnings in the current period.
797468_14_ITEM8_P61_S0	For cash-flow hedges, the gain or loss on the effective portion of the derivative is reported as a component of other comprehensive income (OCI) with an offsetting adjustment to the basis of the item being hedged.
797468_14_ITEM8_P61_S1	Realized gains or losses from cash-flow hedges, and any ineffective portion, are recorded as a component of net sales in the consolidated statements of income.
797468_14_ITEM8_P62_S0	Ineffectiveness is primarily created by a lack of correlation between the hedged item and the hedging instrument due to location, quality, grade or changes in the expected quantity of the hedged item.
797468_14_ITEM8_P63_S0	Gains and losses from derivative instruments are reported net in the consolidated statements of income.
797468_14_ITEM8_P64_S0	There were no fair value hedges as of and during the years ended December 31, 2013 , 2012 and 2011 .
797468_14_ITEM8_P65_S0	A hedge is regarded as highly effective such that it qualifies for hedge accounting if, at inception and throughout its life, it is expected that changes in the fair value or cash flows of the hedged item will be offset by 80 to 125 percent of the changes in the fair value or cash flows, respectively, of the hedging instrument.
797468_14_ITEM8_P66_S0	In the case of hedging a forecast transaction, the transaction must be probable and must present an exposure to variations in cash flows that could ultimately affect reported net income or loss.
797468_14_ITEM8_P66_S1	Occidental discontinues hedge accounting when it determines that a derivative has ceased to be highly effective as a hedge; when the hedged item matures or is sold or repaid; or when a forecast transaction is no longer deemed probable.
797468_14_ITEM8_P67_S0	STOCK-BASED INCENTIVE PLANS Occidental has established several stockholder-approved stock-based incentive plans for certain employees and directors (Plans) that are more fully described in Note 12.
797468_14_ITEM8_P67_S1	A summary of Occidental s accounting policy for awards issued under the Plans is as follows.
797468_14_ITEM8_P68_S0	For cash- and stock-settled restricted stock units or incentive award shares (RSUs), compensation value is initially measured on the grant date using the quoted market price of Occidental s common stock.
797468_14_ITEM8_P68_S1	For cash- and stock-settled total shareholder return incentives (TSRIs), compensation value is initially measured on the grant date using estimated payout levels derived from the Monte Carlo valuation model.
797468_14_ITEM8_P68_S2	Compensation expense for RSUs and TSRIs is recognized on a straight-line basis over the requisite service periods, which is generally over the awards respective vesting or performance periods.
797468_14_ITEM8_P68_S3	Compensation expense for the cash-settled portion of the TSRI awards and related dividends is adjusted quarterly for any changes in stock price and the number of share equivalents expected to be paid based on the relevant performance criteria.
797468_14_ITEM8_P68_S4	For RSUs, compensation expense for the cash-settled portion of the awards is adjusted for changes in the value of the underlying stock on a quarterly basis.
797468_14_ITEM8_P68_S5	All such performance or stock-price-related changes are recognized in periodic compensation expense.
797468_14_ITEM8_P68_S6	The stock-settled portion of these awards is expensed using the initially measured compensation value.
797468_14_ITEM8_P69_S0	EARNINGS PER SHARE Occidental's instruments containing rights to nonforfeitable dividends granted in stock-based awards are considered participating securities prior to vesting and, therefore, have been deducted from earnings in computing basic and diluted EPS under the two-class method.
797468_14_ITEM8_P70_S0	Basic EPS was computed by dividing net income attributable to common stock, net of income allocated to participating securities, by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding during each period, net of treasury shares and including vested but unissued shares and share units.
797468_14_ITEM8_P70_S1	The computation of diluted EPS reflects the additional dilutive effect of stock options and unvested stock awards.
797468_14_ITEM8_P71_S0	RETIREMENT AND POSTRETIREMENT BENEFIT PLANS Occidental recognizes the overfunded or underfunded amounts of its defined benefit pension and postretirement plans in its financial statements using a December 31 measurement date.
797468_14_ITEM8_P72_S0	Occidental determines its defined benefit pension and postretirement benefit plan obligations based on various assumptions and discount rates.
797468_14_ITEM8_P72_S1	The discount rate assumptions used are meant to reflect the interest rate at which the obligations could effectively be settled on the measurement date.
797468_14_ITEM8_P73_S0	Occidental estimates the rate of return on assets with regard to current market factors but within the context of historical returns.
797468_14_ITEM8_P74_S0	Occidental funds and expenses negotiated pension increases for domestic union employees over the terms of the applicable collective bargaining agreements.
797468_14_ITEM8_P75_S0	Pension and any postretirement plan assets are measured at fair value.
797468_14_ITEM8_P76_S0	Common stock, preferred stock, publicly registered mutual funds, U.S. government securities and corporate bonds are valued using quoted market prices in active markets when available.
797468_14_ITEM8_P76_S1	When quoted market prices are not available, these investments are valued using pricing models with observable inputs from both active and non-active markets.
797468_14_ITEM8_P76_S2	Common and collective trusts are valued at the fund units' net asset value (NAV) provided by the issuer, which represents the quoted price in a non-active market.
797468_14_ITEM8_P76_S3	Short-term investment funds are valued at the fund units' NAV provided by the issuer.

797468_14_ITEM8_P79_S1	Occidental reports the exchange rate differences arising from translating foreign-currency-denominated balance sheet accounts to the United States dollar as of the reporting date in other comprehensive income.

797468_14_ITEM8_P103_S0	Operating lease agreements include leases for transportation equipment, power plants, machinery, terminals, storage facilities, land and office space.

797468_14_ITEM8_P106_S0	Objective Strategy Occidental uses a variety of derivative instruments, including cash-flow hedges and derivative instruments not designated as hedging instruments, to obtain the average prices for the relevant production month and to improve realized prices for oil and gas.
797468_14_ITEM8_P106_S1	Occidental only occasionally hedges its oil and gas production, and, when it does so, the volumes are usually insignificant.
797468_14_ITEM8_P106_S2	Additionally, Occidental s Phibro trading unit engages in trading activities using derivatives for the purpose of generating profits mainly from market price changes of commodities.
797468_14_ITEM8_P106_S3	Refer to Note 1 for Occidental s accounting policy on derivatives.
797468_14_ITEM8_P107_S0	Cash-Flow Hedges Occidental entered into financial swap agreements in November 2012 for the sale of a portion of its natural gas production in California.
797468_14_ITEM8_P107_S1	These swap agreements hedge 50 million cubic feet of natural gas per day beginning in January 2013 through March 2014 and qualify as cash-flow hedges.
797468_14_ITEM8_P107_S2	The weighted-average strike price of these swaps is $4.30.
797468_14_ITEM8_P108_S0	Through March 31, 2012, Occidental held financial swap agreements related to the sale of 50 million cubic feet per day of its existing natural gas production from the Rocky Mountain region of the United States that qualified as cash-flow hedges at a weighted-average strike price of $6.07 .
797468_14_ITEM8_P108_S1	Through December 31, 2011, Occidental held a series of collar agreements for 12,000 barrels of oil per day of its domestic production that qualified as cash-flow hedges at a weighted-average strike price that ranged from $32.92 to $46.35 .
797468_14_ITEM8_P109_S0	Occidental s marketing and trading operations store natural gas purchased from third parties at Occidental s North American leased storage facilities.
797468_14_ITEM8_P109_S1	Derivative instruments are used to fix margins on the future sales of the stored volumes through March 31, 2014.
797468_14_ITEM8_P110_S0	As of December 31, 2013 and 2012 , Occidental had approximately 11 billion cubic feet and 20 billion cubic feet of natural gas held in storage, respectively.
797468_14_ITEM8_P110_S1	As of December 31, 2013 and 2012 , Occidental had cash-flow hedges for the forecast sale, to be settled by physical delivery, of approximately 13 billion cubic feet and 20 billion cubic feet of this stored natural gas, respectively.
