797468_15_ITEM15_P53_S0	Title 17, Code of Federal Regulations, Modernization of Oil and Gas Reporting, Final Rule released January 14, 2009 in the Federal Register (SEC regulations).
797468_15_ITEM15_P53_S1	The results of our third party reserves process review, completed on December 30, 2014 and presented herein, were prepared for public disclosure by Occidental in filings made with the SEC in accordance with the disclosure requirements set forth under Section 229.1202(a)(8) of the SEC regulations.
797468_15_ITEM15_P54_S0	Based on our review, including the data, technical processes and interpretations presented by Occidental, it is our opinion that the overall procedures and methodologies utilized by Occidental in estimating the proved reserves volumes, documenting the changes in reserves from prior estimates, preparing the economic evaluations and determining the reserves classifications for the reviewed properties are appropriate for the purpose thereof, and comply with the SEC regulations as of December 31, 2014.
797468_15_ITEM15_P55_S0	Ryder Scott has not been engaged to render an opinion as to the reasonableness of reserves quantities reported by Occidental.
797468_15_ITEM15_P56_S0	The proved reserves reviewed herein are attributable to the fee, leasehold and royalty interests of Occidental in certain properties located in the United States in the state of Texas and derived through Occidental s economic interest as defined in contractual arrangements for certain properties located in the Middle East.
797468_15_ITEM15_P57_S0	The properties reviewed herein were selected by Occidental.
797468_15_ITEM15_P57_S1	Ryder Scott and Occidental concur that these properties are a valid representation of Occidental s total net proved reserves portfolio as of December 31, 2014.
797468_15_ITEM15_P58_S0	Based on the estimates prepared by Occidental, the portion of total company net liquid and net gas reserves reviewed by us are expressed as a percentage and presented in summary form on the following page.
797468_15_ITEM15_P58_S1	At Occidental s request, we have also presented the portion of the total company net reserves reviewed by us on a barrel of oil equivalent (BOE) basis.
797468_15_ITEM15_P59_S0	The net liquid hydrocarbons reviewed are comprised of oil, condensate and natural gas liquids (NGL) and are based on standard 42 gallon barrels.
797468_15_ITEM15_P59_S1	All net gas volumes reviewed are based on an as sold basis expressed in millions of cubic feet (MMCF) at the official temperature and pressure bases of the areas in which the gas reserves are located.
797468_15_ITEM15_P59_S2	Reserves reviewed and noted herein on a BOE basis are based on converting natural gas on the basis of relative energy content using a factor of 6,000 cubic feet of natural gas per one BOE.
797468_15_ITEM15_P59_S3	It should be noted that barrel of oil equivalence does not necessarily result in price equivalence as the equivalent price of natural gas on a BOE basis is, and has been substantially lower than the corresponding price for crude oil currently and for a number of years.
797468_15_ITEM15_P60_S0	A process review, according to Paragraph 2.2(h) contained in the Society of Petroleum Engineers (SPE) Standards Pertaining to the Estimating and Auditing of Oil and Gas Reserves Information (SPE auditing standards), is the result of an investigation by a person who is qualified by experience and training equivalent to that of a Reserves Auditor to address the adequacy and effectiveness of an entity s internal processes and controls relative to reserves estimation.
797468_15_ITEM15_P61_S0	In order to arrive at our conclusions and to substantiate our opinion relative to Occidental s internal reserves estimation process and controls, we conducted our investigation in a manner that closely conforms to the SPE auditing standards for a reserves audit.
797468_15_ITEM15_P61_S1	Under Paragraph 2.2(f) of the SPE auditing standards, a reserves audit includes the process of reviewing certain of the pertinent facts interpreted and assumptions made that have resulted in an estimate of reserves and/or Reserves Information prepared by others and the rendering of an opinion about (1) the appropriateness of the methodologies employed, (2) the adequacy and quality of the data relied upon, (3) the depth and thoroughness of the reserves estimation process, [and] (4) the classification of reserves appropriate to the relevant definitions used.
797468_15_ITEM15_P62_S0	Our process review, however, differs from an SPE reserves audit in that we have not conducted our investigation with sufficient rigor to express an opinion as to the reasonableness of the estimated reserve quantities and/or the Reserves Information as required under item (5) Paragraph 2.2(f) of the SPE auditing standards for a reserves audit.
797468_15_ITEM15_P62_S1	Our review should not be construed to be a complete and comprehensive appraisal of the subject properties or deemed to convey the same level of information contained in a third party reserves audit or reserves evaluation report.
797468_15_ITEM15_P63_S0	Regulations Part 210.4-10(a) released January 14, 2009 in the Federal Register, Volume 74, pages 2158 through 2197.
797468_15_ITEM15_P64_S0	The SEC defines reserves as the estimated remaining quantities of oil and gas and related substances anticipated to be economically producible, as of a given date, by application of development projects to known accumulations.
797468_15_ITEM15_P64_S1	All reserve estimates involve an assessment of the uncertainty relating to the likelihood that the actual remaining quantities recovered will be greater or less than the estimated quantities determined as of the date the estimate is made.
797468_15_ITEM15_P64_S2	The uncertainty depends chiefly on the amount of reliable geologic and engineering data available at the time of the estimate and the interpretation of these data.
797468_15_ITEM15_P64_S3	The relative degree of uncertainty may be conveyed by placing reserves into one of two principal classifications, either proved or unproved.
797468_15_ITEM15_P64_S4	Unproved reserves are less certain to be recovered than proved reserves and may be further sub-classified as probable and possible reserves to denote progressively increasing uncertainty as to their recoverability.
797468_15_ITEM15_P65_S0	In many cases, the analysis of the available geoscience and engineering data and the subsequent interpretation of this data may indicate a range of possible outcomes in an estimate, irrespective of the method selected by the evaluator.
797468_15_ITEM15_P66_S0	When a range in the quantity of reserves is identified, the evaluator must determine the uncertainty associated with the incremental quantities of the reserves.
797468_15_ITEM15_P66_S1	If the reserves quantities are estimated using the deterministic incremental approach, the uncertainty for each discrete incremental quantity of the reserves is addressed by the reserves category assigned by the evaluator.
797468_15_ITEM15_P66_S2	Therefore, it is the categorization of reserve quantities as proved, probable or possible that addresses the inherent uncertainty in the estimated quantities reported.
797468_15_ITEM15_P66_S3	For proved reserves, uncertainty is defined by the SEC as reasonable certainty that the estimates of the quantities actually recovered are much more likely to be achieved than not.
797468_15_ITEM15_P66_S4	The SEC defines probable reserves as those additional reserves that are less certain to be recovered than proved reserves but which, together with proved reserves, are as likely as not to be recovered.
797468_15_ITEM15_P66_S5	The SEC defines possible reserves as those additional reserves that are less certain to be recovered than probable reserves.
797468_15_ITEM15_P66_S6	All quantities of reserves within the same reserves category must meet the SEC definitions as noted above.
797468_15_ITEM15_P67_S0	The reserves for the properties reviewed by us were estimated by Occidental using deterministic methods and presented as incremental quantities.
797468_15_ITEM15_P68_S0	Under the deterministic incremental approach, discrete quantities of reserves are estimated and assigned separately as proved, probable or possible based on their individual level of uncertainty.
797468_15_ITEM15_P68_S1	At Occidental s request, this reserves process review addresses only the proved reserves attributable to the properties reviewed herein.
797468_15_ITEM15_P69_S0	Reserves estimates will generally be revised only as additional geologic or engineering data become available or as economic conditions change.
797468_15_ITEM15_P69_S1	For proved reserves, the SEC states that as changes due to increased availability of geoscience (geological, geophysical, and geochemical), engineering, and economic data are made to the estimated ultimate recovery (EUR) with time, reasonably certain EUR is much more likely to increase or remain constant than to decrease.
797468_15_ITEM15_P69_S2	Moreover, estimates of proved, probable and possible reserves quantities and their associated reserves categories may be revised due to other factors such as the results of future operations, effects of regulation by governmental agencies or geopolitical or economic risks.
797468_15_ITEM15_P70_S0	Certain technical personnel responsible for the preparation of Occidental s proved reserves estimates presented the data, methods and procedures used in 1) estimating the reserves volumes as of December 31, 2014; 2) documenting the changes in reserves from prior estimates; 3) preparing the economic evaluations associated with the estimated December 31, 2014 reserves; and 4) determining the reserves classifications for each of the subject properties reviewed.
797468_15_ITEM15_P70_S1	We consulted with these technical personnel and had access to their workpapers and supporting data in the course of our review.
797468_15_ITEM15_P70_S2	Furthermore, if in the course of our examination something came to our attention which brought into question the appropriateness of the methodologies employed, the adequacy of the data relied upon or the documentation of the reserves estimation process, additional clarification was requested from Occidental until we had satisfactorily resolved our questions relating thereto.
797468_15_ITEM15_P71_S0	The estimation of reserves involves two distinct determinations.
797468_15_ITEM15_P71_S1	The first determination results in the estimation of the quantities of recoverable oil and gas and the second determination results in the estimation of the uncertainty associated with those estimated quantities in accordance with the definitions set forth by the Securities and Exchange Commission s Regulations Part 210.4-10(a).
797468_15_ITEM15_P72_S0	The process of estimating the quantities of recoverable oil and gas reserves relies on the use of certain analytical procedures.
797468_15_ITEM15_P72_S1	These analytical procedures fall into three broad categories or methods: (1) performance-based methods; (2) volumetric-based methods; and (3) analogy.
797468_15_ITEM15_P72_S2	These methods may be used singularly or in combination by the reserves evaluator in the process of estimating the quantities of reserves.
797468_15_ITEM15_P72_S3	Reserves evaluators must select the method or combination of methods which in their professional judgment is most appropriate given the nature and amount of reliable geoscience and engineering data available at the time of the estimate, the established or anticipated performance characteristics of the reservoir being evaluated and the stage of development or producing maturity of the property.
797468_15_ITEM15_P73_S0	The proved reserves for the properties that we reviewed were estimated by performance methods, analogy, reservoir modeling or a combination of methods.
797468_15_ITEM15_P73_S1	Approximately 23 percent of the proved reserves attributable to producing wells or reservoirs for the properties reviewed were estimated by performance methods using decline curve analysis and/or material balance which utilized extrapolations of historical production and pressure data in those cases where such data were considered to be definitive.
797468_15_ITEM15_P73_S2	The remaining 77 percent of the proved reserves attributable to the producing wells for the properties reviewed were estimated by a combination of methods including type curves supported by analogs and reservoir modeling to 1) estimate those reserves where there were inadequate historical performance data to establish a definitive producing trend and 2) estimate the incremental reserves attributable to enhanced/improved oil recovery.
797468_15_ITEM15_P73_S3	The data used by Occidental in their analysis of the proved reserves for the producing properties reviewed by us was considered sufficient for the purpose thereof.
797468_15_ITEM15_P74_S0	Approximately 2 percent of the proved developed non-producing reserves were estimated by performance methods using analogy to prior established decline trends.
797468_15_ITEM15_P74_S1	The remaining 98 percent of the proved developed non-producing reserves and all of the proved undeveloped reserves were estimated by a combination of methods including volumetrics and type curves supported by analogs and reservoir modeling as noted above.
797468_15_ITEM15_P74_S2	The data used by Occidental in their analysis of the non-producing and undeveloped reserves for the properties reviewed by us was considered sufficient for the purpose thereof.
797468_15_ITEM15_P75_S0	Of the properties reviewed, approximately 94 percent of the proved producing reserves and 42 percent of the proved non-producing and undeveloped reserve volumes are related to the application of enhanced/improved recovery techniques.
797468_15_ITEM15_P75_S1	These enhanced/improved recovery techniques include water and CO 2 injection and infill drilling.
797468_15_ITEM15_P76_S0	Occidental uses the latest available production, new well and seismic data in its reserves estimation process.
797468_15_ITEM15_P76_S1	Typically, this data is from the third quarter of the year for which reserves are estimated, though material data is considered whenever it becomes available prior to finalization of reserves estimates.
797468_15_ITEM15_P76_S2	The data used by Occidental in their analysis of the proved reserves for the properties reviewed by us was considered sufficient for the purpose thereof.
797468_15_ITEM15_P77_S0	To estimate economically recoverable proved reserves and related future net cash flows, Occidental considered many factors and assumptions including, but not limited to, the use of reservoir parameters derived from geological, geophysical and engineering data which cannot be measured directly, economic criteria based on current costs and SEC pricing requirements, and forecasts of future production rates.
797468_15_ITEM15_P78_S0	Under the SEC regulations 210.4-10(a)(22)(v) and (26), proved reserves must be anticipated to be economically producible from a given date forward based on existing economic conditions including the prices and costs at which economic producibility from a reservoir is to be determined.
797468_15_ITEM15_P78_S1	To confirm that the proved reserves reviewed by us meet the SEC requirements to be economically producible, we have reviewed certain primary economic data utilized by Occidental relating to hydrocarbon prices and costs as noted herein.
797468_15_ITEM15_P79_S0	The hydrocarbon prices in effect on December 31, 2014 for the properties reviewed were determined by Occidental using the unweighted 12-month average first-day-of-the-month benchmark prices appropriate to the geographic area where the hydrocarbons are sold and adjustments for differentials as described herein.
797468_15_ITEM15_P80_S0	In certain geographic areas, the price reference and benchmark prices may be defined by contractual arrangements.
797468_15_ITEM15_P80_S1	For hydrocarbon products sold under contract, the contract prices including fixed and determinable escalations, exclusive of inflation adjustments, were used until expiration of the contract.
797468_15_ITEM15_P81_S0	The table below summarizes Occidental s net volume weighted benchmark prices adjusted for differentials for the properties reviewed by us and referred to herein as Occidental s average realized prices.
797468_15_ITEM15_P81_S1	The average realized prices shown in the table below were determined from Occidental s estimate of the total future gross revenue before production taxes for the properties reviewed by us and Occidental s estimate of the total net reserves for the properties reviewed by us for the geographic area.
797468_15_ITEM15_P81_S2	A summary of average realized prices are not included for properties located in the Middle East because of host government s limitations on the disclosure of commercially sensitive information.
797468_15_ITEM15_P82_S0	The data shown in the table below is presented in accordance with SEC disclosure requirements for each of the geographic areas reviewed by us.
797468_15_ITEM15_P83_S0	As indicated above, the product prices that were used by Occidental to determine the future gross revenue for each property reviewed by us reflect adjustments to the benchmark prices for gravity, quality, local conditions, gathering and transportation fees and distance from market, referred to herein as differentials.
797468_15_ITEM15_P83_S1	The differentials used by Occidental were accepted as factual data.
797468_15_ITEM15_P83_S2	We have not conducted an independent verification of the data used by Occidental.
797468_15_ITEM15_P84_S0	While it may reasonably be anticipated that the future prices received for the sale of production and the operating costs and other costs relating to such production may also increase or decrease from existing levels, such changes were, in accordance with rules adopted by the SEC, omitted from consideration by Occidental in this process and omitted by us in conducting this review.
797468_15_ITEM15_P85_S0	Accumulated gas production imbalances, if any, were not taken into account in the proved reserve estimates of gas reviewed.
797468_15_ITEM15_P85_S1	The proved gas volumes included herein attribute gas consumed in operations as reserves for those fields where the inclusion of such volumes was appropriate.
797468_15_ITEM15_P86_S0	Operating costs used by Occidental are based on the operating expense reports of Occidental and include only those costs directly applicable to the leases or wells for the properties reviewed by us.
797468_15_ITEM15_P86_S1	The operating costs include a portion of general and administrative costs allocated directly to the leases and wells.
797468_15_ITEM15_P86_S2	For operated properties, the operating costs include an appropriate level of corporate general administrative and overhead costs.
797468_15_ITEM15_P86_S3	The operating costs for non-operated properties include the Council of Petroleum Accounting Societies overhead costs that are allocated directly to the leases and wells under terms of operating agreements.
797468_15_ITEM15_P86_S4	The operating costs used by Occidental were accepted as factual data and reviewed by us for their reasonableness; however, we have not conducted an independent verification of the data used by Occidental.

797468_15_ITEM15_P87_S1	The development costs used by Occidental were accepted as factual data and reviewed by us for their reasonableness; however, we have not conducted an independent verification of the data used by Occidental.

797468_15_ITEM15_P89_S0	Occidental s forecasts of future production rates are based on historical performance from wells currently on production.
797468_15_ITEM15_P89_S1	If no production decline trend has been established, future production rates were held constant, or adjusted for the effects of curtailment where appropriate, until a decline in ability to produce was anticipated.
797468_15_ITEM15_P89_S2	An estimated rate of decline was then applied to depletion of the reserves.
797468_15_ITEM15_P90_S0	If a decline trend has been established, this trend was used as the basis for estimating future production rates.
797468_15_ITEM15_P91_S0	Test data and other related information were used by Occidental to estimate the anticipated initial production rates for those wells or locations that are not currently producing.
797468_15_ITEM15_P91_S1	For reserves not yet on production, sales were estimated to commence at an anticipated date determined by Occidental.
797468_15_ITEM15_P91_S2	Wells or locations that are not currently producing may start producing earlier or later than anticipated in Occidental s estimates due to unforeseen factors causing a change in the timing to initiate production.
797468_15_ITEM15_P91_S3	Such factors may include delays due to weather, the availability of rigs, the sequence of drilling, completing or recompleting wells and constraints set by regulatory bodies.
797468_15_ITEM15_P92_S0	The future production rates from wells currently on production or wells or locations that are not currently producing may be more or less than estimated by Occidental because of changes including, but not limited to, reservoir performance, operating conditions related to surface facilities, compression and artificial lift, pipeline capacity or other operating conditions, market demand and allowables or other constraints set by regulatory bodies.

797468_15_ITEM15_P117_S0	On January 14, 2009, the United States Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) published the Modernization of Oil and Gas Reporting; Final Rule in the Federal Register of National Archives and Records Administration (NARA).
797468_15_ITEM15_P117_S1	The Modernization of Oil and Gas Reporting; Final Rule includes revisions and additions to the definition section in Rule 4-10 of Regulation S-X, revisions and additions to the oil and gas reporting requirements in Regulation S-K, and amends and codifies Industry Guide 2 in Regulation S-K.
797468_15_ITEM15_P117_S2	The Modernization of Oil and Gas Reporting; Final Rule , including all references to Regulation S-X and Regulation S-K, shall be referred to herein collectively as the SEC regulations .
797468_15_ITEM15_P118_S0	The SEC regulations take effect for all filings made with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission as of December 31, 2009, or after January 1, 2010.
797468_15_ITEM15_P118_S1	Reference should be made to the full text under Title 17, Code of Federal Regulations, Regulation S-X Part 210, Rule 4-10(a) for the complete definitions (direct passages excerpted in part or wholly from the aforementioned SEC document are denoted in italics herein).
797468_15_ITEM15_P119_S0	Reserves are estimated remaining quantities of oil and gas and related substances anticipated to be economically producible, as of a given date, by application of development projects to known accumulations.
797468_15_ITEM15_P119_S1	All reserve estimates involve an assessment of the uncertainty relating the likelihood that the actual remaining quantities recovered will be greater or less than the estimated quantities determined as of the date the estimate is made.
797468_15_ITEM15_P119_S2	The uncertainty depends chiefly on the amount of reliable geologic and engineering data available at the time of the estimate and the interpretation of these data.
797468_15_ITEM15_P119_S3	The relative degree of uncertainty may be conveyed by placing reserves into one of two principal classifications, either proved or unproved.
797468_15_ITEM15_P119_S4	Unproved reserves are less certain to be recovered than proved reserves and may be further sub-classified as probable and possible reserves to denote progressively increasing uncertainty in their recoverability.
797468_15_ITEM15_P120_S0	Under the SEC regulations as of December 31, 2009, or after January 1, 2010, a company may optionally disclose estimated quantities of probable or possible oil and gas reserves in documents publicly filed with the SEC.
797468_15_ITEM15_P120_S1	The SEC regulations continue to prohibit disclosure of estimates of oil and gas resources other than reserves and any estimated values of such resources in any document publicly filed with the SEC unless such information is required to be disclosed in the document by foreign or state law as noted in 229.1202 Instruction to Item 1202.
797468_15_ITEM15_P121_S0	Reserves estimates will generally be revised only as additional geologic or engineering data become available or as economic conditions change.
797468_15_ITEM15_P122_S0	Reserves may be attributed to either natural energy or improved recovery methods.
797468_15_ITEM15_P122_S1	Improved recovery methods include all methods for supplementing natural energy or altering natural forces in the reservoir to increase ultimate recovery.
797468_15_ITEM15_P122_S2	Examples of such methods are pressure maintenance, natural gas cycling, waterflooding, thermal methods, chemical flooding, and the use of miscible and immiscible displacement fluids.
797468_15_ITEM15_P122_S3	Other improved recovery methods may be developed in the future as petroleum technology continues to evolve.
797468_15_ITEM15_P123_S0	Reserves may be attributed to either conventional or unconventional petroleum accumulations.
797468_15_ITEM15_P124_S0	Petroleum accumulations are considered as either conventional or unconventional based on the nature of their in-place characteristics, extraction method applied, or degree of processing prior to sale.
797468_15_ITEM15_P125_S0	Examples of unconventional petroleum accumulations include coalbed or coalseam methane (CBM/CSM), basin-centered gas, shale gas, gas hydrates, natural bitumen and oil shale deposits.
797468_15_ITEM15_P125_S1	These unconventional accumulations may require specialized extraction technology and/or significant processing prior to sale.
797468_15_ITEM15_P126_S0	Reserves do not include quantities of petroleum being held in inventory.
797468_15_ITEM15_P127_S0	Because of the differences in uncertainty, caution should be exercised when aggregating quantities of petroleum from different reserves categories.
797468_15_ITEM15_P128_S0	Securities and Exchange Commission Regulation S-X 210.4-10(a)(26) defines reserves as follows:
797468_15_ITEM15_P129_S0	Reserves are estimated remaining quantities of oil and gas and related substances anticipated to be economically producible, as of a given date, by application of development projects to known accumulations.
797468_15_ITEM15_P129_S1	In addition, there must exist, or there must be a reasonable expectation that there will exist, the legal right to produce or a revenue interest in the production, installed means of delivering oil and gas or related substances to market, and all permits and financing required to implement the project.
797468_15_ITEM15_P130_S0	Note to paragraph (a)(26): Reserves should not be assigned to adjacent reservoirs isolated by major, potentially sealing, faults until those reservoirs are penetrated and evaluated as economically producible.
797468_15_ITEM15_P130_S1	Reserves should not be assigned to areas that are clearly separated from a known accumulation by a non-productive reservoir ( i.e. , absence of reservoir, structurally low reservoir, or negative test results).
797468_15_ITEM15_P130_S2	Such areas may contain prospective resources ( i.e. , potentially recoverable resources from undiscovered accumulations).
797468_15_ITEM15_P131_S0	Securities and Exchange Commission Regulation S-X 210.4-10(a)(22) defines proved oil and gas reserves as follows:
797468_15_ITEM15_P132_S0	Proved oil and gas reserves are those quantities of oil and gas, which, by analysis of geoscience and engineering data, can be estimated with reasonable certainty to be economically producible from a given date forward, from known reservoirs, and under existing economic conditions, operating methods, and government regulations prior to the time at which contracts providing the right to operate expire, unless evidence indicates that renewal is reasonably certain, regardless of whether deterministic or probabilistic methods are used for the estimation.
797468_15_ITEM15_P132_S1	The project to extract the hydrocarbons must have commenced or the operator must be reasonably certain that it will commence the project within a reasonable time.
797468_15_ITEM15_P133_S0	The area of the reservoir considered as proved includes:
797468_15_ITEM15_P134_S0	Adjacent undrilled portions of the reservoir that can, with reasonable certainty, be judged to be continuous with it and to contain economically producible oil or gas on the basis of available geoscience and engineering data.
797468_15_ITEM15_P135_S0	In the absence of data on fluid contacts, proved quantities in a reservoir are limited by the lowest known hydrocarbons (LKH) as seen in a well penetration unless geoscience, engineering, or performance data and reliable technology establishes a lower contact with reasonable certainty.
797468_15_ITEM15_P136_S0	(iii) Where direct observation from well penetrations has defined a highest known oil (HKO) elevation and the potential exists for an associated gas cap, proved oil reserves may be assigned in the structurally higher portions of the reservoir only if geoscience, engineering, or performance data and reliable technology establish the higher contact with reasonable certainty.
797468_15_ITEM15_P137_S0	The project has been approved for development by all necessary parties and entities, including governmental entities.
797468_15_ITEM15_P138_S0	(v) Existing economic conditions include prices and costs at which economic producibility from a reservoir is to be determined.
797468_15_ITEM15_P138_S1	The price shall be the average price during the 12-month period prior to the ending date of the period covered by the report, determined as an unweighted arithmetic average of the first-day-of-the-month price for each month within such period, unless prices are defined by contractual arrangements, excluding escalations based upon future conditions.
797468_15_ITEM15_P139_S0	Reserves status categories define the development and producing status of wells and reservoirs.
797468_15_ITEM15_P139_S1	Reference should be made to Title 17, Code of Federal Regulations, Regulation S-X Part 210, Rule 4-10(a) and the SPE-PRMS as the following reserves status definitions are based on excerpts from the original documents (direct passages excerpted from the aforementioned SEC and SPE-PRMS documents are denoted in italics herein).
797468_15_ITEM15_P140_S0	Securities and Exchange Commission Regulation S-X 210.4-10(a)(6) defines developed oil and gas reserves as follows:
797468_15_ITEM15_P141_S0	Developed oil and gas reserves are reserves of any category that can be expected to be recovered:
797468_15_ITEM15_P142_S0	Through installed extraction equipment and infrastructure operational at the time of the reserves estimate if the extraction is by means not involving a well.
797468_15_ITEM15_P143_S0	While not a requirement for disclosure under the SEC regulations, developed oil and gas reserves may be further sub-classified according to the guidance contained in the SPE-PRMS as Producing or Non-Producing.
797468_15_ITEM15_P144_S0	Developed Producing Reserves Developed Producing Reserves are expected to be recovered from completion intervals that are open and producing at the time of the estimate.
797468_15_ITEM15_P145_S0	Improved recovery reserves are considered producing only after the improved recovery project is in operation.
797468_15_ITEM15_P146_S0	Developed Non-Producing Developed Non-Producing Reserves include shut-in and behind-pipe reserves.
797468_15_ITEM15_P147_S0	Shut-In Shut-in Reserves are expected to be recovered from: (1) completion intervals which are open at the time of the estimate, but which have not started producing; (2) wells which were shut-in for market conditions or pipeline connections; or (3) wells not capable of production for mechanical reasons.
797468_15_ITEM15_P148_S0	Behind-Pipe Behind-pipe Reserves are expected to be recovered from zones in existing wells, which will require additional completion work or future re-completion prior to start of production.
797468_15_ITEM15_P149_S0	In all cases, production can be initiated or restored with relatively low expenditure compared to the cost of drilling a new well.
797468_15_ITEM15_P150_S0	Securities and Exchange Commission Regulation S-X 210.4-10(a)(31) defines undeveloped oil and gas reserves as follows:
797468_15_ITEM15_P151_S0	Undeveloped oil and gas reserves are reserves of any category that are expected to be recovered from new wells on undrilled acreage, or from existing wells where a relatively major expenditure is required for recompletion.
797468_15_ITEM15_P152_S0	(i) Reserves on undrilled acreage shall be limited to those directly offsetting development spacing areas that are reasonably certain of production when drilled, unless evidence using reliable technology exists that establishes reasonable certainty of economic producibility at greater distances.
797468_15_ITEM15_P153_S0	(ii) Undrilled locations can be classified as having undeveloped reserves only if a development plan has been adopted indicating that they are scheduled to be drilled within five years, unless the specific circumstances, justify a longer time.
797468_15_ITEM15_P154_S0	(iii) Under no circumstances shall estimates for undeveloped reserves be attributable to any acreage for which an application of fluid injection or other improved recovery technique is contemplated, unless such techniques have been proved effective by actual projects in the same reservoir or an analogous reservoir, as defined in [Regulation S-X 210.4-10(a)(2)] , or by other evidence using reliable technology establishing reasonable certainty.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Occidental's financial results correlate closely to the prices it obtains for its products, particularly oil and, to a lesser extent, natural gas and NGLs, and its chemical products.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Prices for crude oil, natural gas and NGLs fluctuate widely.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Historically, the markets for crude oil, natural gas, NGLs and refined products have been volatile and may continue to be volatile in the future.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P0_S3	Prolonged or further declines in crude oil, natural gas and NGLs prices would continue to reduce Occidental's operating results and cash flows, and could impact its future rate of growth and further impact the recoverability of the carrying value of its assets.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Prices are set by global and local market forces which are not in Occidental's control.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Worldwide and domestic supplies of, and demand for, crude oil, natural gas, NGLs and refined products.

797468_16_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Operational impacts such as production disruptions, technological advances and regional market conditions, including available transportation capacity and infrastructure constraints in producing areas.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Changes in weather patterns and climatic changes.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P6_S0	The impacts of the members of OPEC and other producing nations that may agree to and maintain production levels.

797468_16_ITEM1A_P8_S0	The price and availability of alternative and competing fuels.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Domestic and foreign governmental regulations and taxes.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Additional or increased nationalization and expropriation activities by foreign governments.

797468_16_ITEM1A_P11_S1	Generally, Occidental's practice is to remain exposed to market prices of commodities; however, management may elect to hedge the price risk of crude oil, natural gas, NGLs and refined products in the future.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P11_S2	Recent global economic and political conditions have driven oil and gas prices down significantly.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P11_S3	These conditions may continue for an extended period.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P11_S4	Continued reductions in commodity prices could require Occidental to further reduce capital spending, share repurchases and impair the carrying value of assets.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P12_S0	The prices obtained for Occidental s chemical products correlate strongly to the health of the United States and global economies, as well as chemical industry expansion and contraction cycles.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P12_S1	Occidental also depends on feedstocks and energy to produce chemicals, which are commodities subject to significant price fluctuations.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Occidental's restructuring activities may affect its stock price.

797468_16_ITEM1A_P13_S2	This activity and further implementation of the strategic review may affect the market value of Occidental's common stock.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P13_S3	For example, Occidental may take different actions than expected, receive less proceeds or retain more liabilities than anticipated in connection with any divestitures.

797468_16_ITEM1A_P15_S0	ability to profitably grow production, replace reserves and achieve its targeted returns.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Exploration is inherently risky and is subject to delays, misinterpretation of geologic or engineering data, unexpected geologic conditions or finding reserves of disappointing quality or quantity, which may result in significant losses.

797468_16_ITEM1A_P17_S1	Occidental s businesses are subject to the decisions of many federal, state, local and foreign governments and political interests.

797468_16_ITEM1A_P18_S0	New or amended laws and regulations, or interpretations of such laws and regulations, including those related to drilling, manufacturing or production processes (including well stimulation techniques such as hydraulic fracturing and acidization), labor and employment, taxes, royalty rates, permitted production rates, entitlements, import, export and use of raw materials, equipment or products, use or increased use of land, water and other natural resources, safety, security and environmental protection, all of which may restrict or prohibit activities of Occidental or its contractors, increase Occidental's costs or reduce demand for Occidental's products.

797468_16_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Occidental's oil and gas business operates in highly competitive environments, which affect, among other things, its ability to make acquisitions to grow production and replace reserves.

797468_16_ITEM1A_P24_S0	Occidental s oil and gas reserves are estimates based on professional judgments and may be subject to revision.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P24_S1	Reported oil and gas reserves are an estimate based on periodic review of reservoir characteristics and recoverability, including production decline rates, operating performance and economic feasibility at the prevailing commodity prices, assumptions concerning future crude oil and natural gas prices, future operating costs and capital expenditures, as well as assumed effects of regulation by governmental agencies.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P25_S0	The procedures and methods for estimating the reserves by our internal engineers were reviewed by independent petroleum consultants; however, there are inherent uncertainties in estimating reserves.

797468_16_ITEM1A_P25_S2	If Occidental were required to make significant negative reserve revisions, its results of operations and stock price could be adversely affected.

797468_16_ITEM1A_P28_S2	Third-party insurance may not provide adequate coverage or Occidental may be self-insured with respect to the related losses.

797468_16_ITEM1A_P30_S0	Cyber attacks on businesses have escalated in recent years.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P30_S1	Occidental relies on electronic systems and networks to control and manage its oil and gas, chemicals, trading and pipeline operations and has multiple layers of security to mitigate risks of cyber attack.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P30_S2	If, however, Occidental were to experience an attack and its security measures were compromised, the potential consequences to its businesses and the communities in which it operates could be significant.
797468_16_ITEM1A_P31_S0	Occidental's oil and gas reserve additions may not continue at the same rate and a failure to replace reserves may negatively affect our business.

797468_16_ITEM7_P0_S0	In this report, "Occidental" means Occidental Petroleum Corporation (OPC), or OPC and one or more entities in which it owns a controlling interest (subsidiaries).
797468_16_ITEM7_P1_S0	Occidental's principal businesses consist of three segments.
797468_16_ITEM7_P2_S0	The oil and gas segment explores for, develops and produces oil and condensate, natural gas liquids (NGLs) and natural gas.
797468_16_ITEM7_P2_S1	The chemical segment (OxyChem) mainly manufactures and markets basic chemicals and vinyls.
797468_16_ITEM7_P3_S0	The midstream and marketing segment gathers, processes, transports, stores, purchases and markets oil, condensate, NGLs, natural gas, carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) and power.
797468_16_ITEM7_P3_S1	It also trades around its assets, including transportation and storage capacity.
797468_16_ITEM7_P3_S2	Additionally, the midstream and marketing segment invests in entities that conduct similar activities.
797468_16_ITEM7_P4_S0	STRATEGY General Through its operations, Occidental aims to maximize total returns to stockholders using the following strategies:
797468_16_ITEM7_P5_S0	Maintain financial discipline and a strong balance sheet.
797468_16_ITEM7_P6_S0	In conducting its business, Occidental accepts commodity, engineering and limited exploration risks.
797468_16_ITEM7_P6_S1	Capital is employed to operate all assets in a safe and environmentally sound manner.
797468_16_ITEM7_P7_S0	Occidental seeks to limit its financial and political risks.
797468_16_ITEM7_P8_S0	Price volatility is inherent in the oil and gas business, and in 2015, oil, natural gas and NGLs prices continued the downward trend started in the fourth quarter of 2014.
797468_16_ITEM7_P8_S1	In order to manage this risk, Occidental strives to retain sufficient cash on hand and maintain a low debt to capitalization ratio, which allows Occidental access to capital markets.
797468_16_ITEM7_P8_S2	In connection with Occidental's strategic review initiatives, Occidental:
797468_16_ITEM7_P9_S0	Minimized or ceased its involvement in non-core operations in the Middle East and North Africa, including Bahrain, Iraq, Libya and Yemen.
797468_16_ITEM7_P10_S0	As a result of exiting non-core operations, Occidental expects improved margins through lower cash operating costs, selling, general and administrative costs and reduced capital spending in the future.
797468_16_ITEM7_P11_S0	The following describes the application of Occidental s overall strategy for each of its operating segments:
797468_16_ITEM7_P12_S0	Oil and Gas The oil and gas business implements Occidental's strategy primarily by:
797468_16_ITEM7_P13_S0	Maintaining a disciplined approach towards domestic acquisitions and divestitures and the execution of international contracts, with an emphasis on creating value and further enhancing Occidental's existing positions.
797468_16_ITEM7_P14_S0	In 2015, oil and gas capital expenditures were approximately $4.4 billion, and were mainly comprised of expenditures in the Permian Basin and the Middle East.
797468_16_ITEM7_P14_S1	This activity reflects Occidental's strategy to focus on achieving returns above the cost of capital even in a low price environment.
797468_16_ITEM7_P14_S2	Management believes Occidental's oil and gas segment growth will occur primarily through exploitation and development opportunities in the Permian Basin and Colombia and focused international projects in the Middle East.
797468_16_ITEM7_P15_S0	Chemical The primary objective of OxyChem is to generate cash flow in excess of its normal capital expenditure requirements and achieve above-cost-of-capital returns.
797468_16_ITEM7_P15_S1	The chemical segment's strategy is to be a low-cost producer in order to maximize its cash flow generation.
797468_16_ITEM7_P16_S0	OxyChem concentrates on the chlorovinyls chain beginning with chlorine, which is co-produced with caustic soda, and markets both to third parties.
797468_16_ITEM7_P16_S1	In addition, chlorine, together with ethylene, is converted through a series of intermediate products into polyvinyl chloride (PVC).
797468_16_ITEM7_P16_S2	OxyChem's focus on chlorovinyls allows it to maximize the benefits of integration and take advantage of economies of scale.
797468_16_ITEM7_P16_S3	Capital is employed to sustain production capacity and to focus on projects and developments designed to improve the competitiveness of segment assets.
797468_16_ITEM7_P16_S4	Acquisitions and plant development opportunities may be pursued when they are expected to enhance the existing core chlor-alkali and PVC businesses or take advantage of other specific opportunities.
797468_16_ITEM7_P17_S0	2014, OxyChem, through a 50/50 joint venture with Mexichem S.A.B. de C.V., broke ground on a 1.2 billion pound-per-year ethylene cracker at the OxyChem Ingleside facility.
797468_16_ITEM7_P17_S1	The joint venture provides an opportunity to capitalize on the advantage that U.S. shale gas development has presented to U.S. chemical producers by providing low-cost ethane as a raw material.

797468_16_ITEM7_P19_S1	In order to generate returns, the segment evaluates opportunities across the value chain and uses its assets to provide services to other Occidental segments as well as third parties.
797468_16_ITEM7_P19_S2	The segment invests and operates pipeline systems, gas plants, co-generation facilities, and storage facilities.
797468_16_ITEM7_P19_S3	The segment also seeks to minimize the costs of gas, power and other commodities used in Occidental's businesses, while limiting credit risk exposure.

797468_16_ITEM7_P32_S0	Domestic Interests Occidental conducts its domestic operations through land leases, subsurface mineral rights it owns or a combination of both surface land and subsurface mineral rights it owns.
797468_16_ITEM7_P32_S1	Occidental's domestic oil and gas leases have a primary term ranging from one to ten years, which is extended through the end of production once it commences.

797468_16_ITEM7_P33_S0	Production-Sharing Contracts Occidental's interests in Oman and Qatar are subject to production sharing contracts (PSC).
797468_16_ITEM7_P33_S1	Under such contracts, Occidental records a share of production and reserves to recover certain production costs and an additional share for profit.
797468_16_ITEM7_P33_S2	In addition, certain contracts in Colombia are subject to contractual arrangements similar to a PSC.
797468_16_ITEM7_P33_S3	These contracts do not transfer any right of ownership to Occidental and reserves reported from these arrangements are based on Occidental s economic interest as defined in the contracts.
797468_16_ITEM7_P33_S4	Occidental s share of production and reserves from these contracts decreases when product prices rise and increases when prices decline.
797468_16_ITEM7_P33_S5	Overall, Occidental s net economic benefit from these contracts is greater when product prices are higher.

797468_16_ITEM7_P36_S0	Permian Basin Occidental's Permian Basin production is diversified across a large number of producing areas.
797468_16_ITEM7_P36_S1	The basin extends throughout southwest Texas and southeast New Mexico and is one of the largest and most active oil basins in the United States, accounting for approximately 16 percent of the total United States oil production.
797468_16_ITEM7_P36_S2	Occidental is the largest operator and the largest producer of oil in the Permian Basin with an approximate 13 percent net share of the total oil production in the basin.
797468_16_ITEM7_P36_S3	Occidental also produces and processes natural gas and NGLs in the basin.
797468_16_ITEM7_P37_S0	Occidental manages its Permian Basin operations through two business units: Permian Resources, which includes growth-oriented unconventional opportunities and Permian EOR (enhanced oil recovery), which utilizes enhanced oil recovery techniques such as CO 2 floods and waterfloods.
797468_16_ITEM7_P37_S1	During 2015 , focused on capital efficiency, the Permian operations reduced well drilling and completion costs by 33 percent per well.
797468_16_ITEM7_P37_S2	In the Permian Basin, Occidental spent over $2.7 billion of capital in 2015 , with 84 percent spent on Permian Resources assets.
797468_16_ITEM7_P37_S3	In 2016 , Occidental expects to allocate approximately 21 percent of the 2016 capital budget to Permian Resources, which will focus on areas in both the Midland and Delaware Basins where infrastructure currently exists to achieve higher returns, and approximately 17 percent to Permian EOR in order to add to existing facilities to increase CO 2 production and injection capacity for future projects.
797468_16_ITEM7_P38_S0	Occidental's Permian Resources operations are among its fastest growing assets with over 8,500 drilling locations in its horizontal inventory, a sizable portion of which can be developed in a low price environment.
797468_16_ITEM7_P38_S1	Continued completion optimization, the application of enhanced manufacturing principles, combined with projected commercial savings is expected to increase the well inventory even further.
797468_16_ITEM7_P38_S2	The development program, largely began in 2010, continued to increase in 2015 .
797468_16_ITEM7_P39_S0	In 2015, Permian Resources drilled 231 wells, which included 195 horizontal wells.
797468_16_ITEM7_P39_S1	Production from Permian Resources comes from approximately 13,200 gross wells, of which 62 percent are operated by other producers.
797468_16_ITEM7_P39_S2	On a net basis, this represents approximately 5,550 wells, of which only 23 percent are operated by others.
797468_16_ITEM7_P40_S0	Permian EOR operates a combination of CO 2 floods and waterfloods which have similar development characteristics and ongoing monitoring and maintenance requirements.
797468_16_ITEM7_P40_S1	Due to a unique combination of characteristics, the Permian Basin has been a leader in the implementation of CO 2 enhanced oil recovery projects.
797468_16_ITEM7_P40_S2	The Permian Basin s concentration of large conventional reservoirs, favorable CO 2 flooding performance and the proximity to naturally occurring CO 2 supply has resulted in decades of steady growth in enhanced oil production.
797468_16_ITEM7_P40_S3	With 31 active floods and 40 years of experience, Permian EOR is the industry leader in Permian Basin CO 2 flooding.
797468_16_ITEM7_P40_S4	Occidental is an industry leader in applying this technology, which can increase ultimate oil recovery by 10 to 25 percent in the fields where it is employed.
797468_16_ITEM7_P40_S5	Significant opportunity remains to expand Occidental's existing projects into new portions of reservoirs that thus far have only been water flooded, leaving opportunity for significant additional recovery with new CO 2 injection.
797468_16_ITEM7_P40_S6	Hence, even small improvements in recovery efficiency can add significant reserves.
797468_16_ITEM7_P40_S7	Technology improvements, such as the recent trend towards vertical expansion of the CO 2 flooded interval into residual oil zone targets continue to yield more recovery from existing projects.
797468_16_ITEM7_P41_S0	Over the last few years, Occidental has had an ongoing program of deepening wells, with 95 wells deepened in 2015 and 67 wells planned for 2016 .
797468_16_ITEM7_P41_S1	Occidental utilizes workover rigs to drill the extra depth into additional CO 2 floodable sections of the reservoir.
797468_16_ITEM7_P41_S2	These are low cost projects which can add reserves even in a low price environment.
797468_16_ITEM7_P42_S0	has a large inventory of future CO 2 projects which could be developed over the next 20 years or accelerated, depending on market conditions.
797468_16_ITEM7_P43_S0	The current strategy for Permian EOR is to invest sufficient capital to maintain current production and provide cash flow.
797468_16_ITEM7_P43_S1	By exploiting natural synergies between Permian EOR and Permian Resources, Occidental is able to deliver unique advantages, efficiencies and expertise across its Permian Basin operations.
797468_16_ITEM7_P43_S2	Occidental's share of production in the Permian Basin was approximately 255,000 BOE per day in 2015 with 110,000 BOE per day coming from Permian Resources and 145,000 BOE per day from Permian EOR.

797468_16_ITEM7_P53_S0	Proved Reserves Proved oil, NGLs and gas reserves were estimated using the unweighted arithmetic average of the first-day-of-the-month price for each month within the year, unless prices were defined by contractual arrangements.
797468_16_ITEM7_P53_S1	Oil, NGLs and natural gas prices used for this purpose were based on posted benchmark prices and adjusted for price differentials including gravity, quality and transportation costs.
797468_16_ITEM7_P53_S2	For the 2015 , 2014 and 2013 disclosures, the calculated average West Texas Intermediate oil prices were $50.28, $94.99 and $96.94 per barrel, respectively.
797468_16_ITEM7_P53_S3	The calculated average Brent oil prices for 2015 , 2014 and 2013 disclosures were $55.57, $99.51 and $108.76, per barrel, respectively.
797468_16_ITEM7_P53_S4	The calculated average Henry Hub gas prices for 2015 , 2014 and 2013 were $2.66, $4.42 and $3.65 per MMBtu, respectively.
797468_16_ITEM7_P53_S5	Occidental had proved reserves at year-end 2015 of 2,200 million BOE, compared to the year-end 2014 amount of 2,819 million BOE.
797468_16_ITEM7_P53_S6	Proved reserves at year-end 2015 and 2014 consisted of, respectively, 59 percent and 63 percent oil, 15 percent and 13 percent NGLs and 26 percent and 24 percent natural gas.
797468_16_ITEM7_P53_S7	Proved developed reserves represented approximately 79 percent and 71 percent, respectively, of Occidental s total proved reserves at year-end 2015 and 2014 .
797468_16_ITEM7_P54_S0	Occidental does not have any reserves from non-traditional sources.
797468_16_ITEM7_P55_S0	Changes in Proved Reserves Occidental's total proved reserves decreased 166 million BOE in 2015 , which included additions of 149 million BOE from Occidental's development program, reduced by 315 million BOE comprised primarily of price and price related revisions.
797468_16_ITEM7_P55_S1	Changes in reserves before production and sales of proved reserves were as follows:
797468_16_ITEM7_P56_S0	Occidental's ability to add reserves, other than through purchases, depends on the success of improved recovery, extension and discovery projects, each of which depends on reservoir characteristics, technology improvements and oil and natural gas prices, as well as capital and operating costs.
797468_16_ITEM7_P56_S1	Many of these factors are outside management s control, and may negatively or positively affect Occidental's reserves.
797468_16_ITEM7_P57_S0	In 2015 , Occidental added proved reserves of 144 million BOE mainly associated with the Permian Basin and Oman operations.
797468_16_ITEM7_P57_S1	These properties comprise both conventional projects, which are characterized by the deployment of EOR development methods, largely employing application of CO 2 flood, waterflood or steam flood, and unconventional projects.
797468_16_ITEM7_P57_S2	These types of conventional EOR development methods can be applied through existing wells, though additional drilling is frequently required to fully optimize the development configuration.
797468_16_ITEM7_P58_S0	Waterflooding is the technique of injecting water into the formation to displace the oil to the offsetting oil production wells.
797468_16_ITEM7_P58_S1	The use of either CO 2 or steam flooding depends on the geology of the formation, the evaluation of engineering data, availability and cost of either CO 2 or steam and other economic factors.
797468_16_ITEM7_P58_S2	Both techniques work similarly to lower viscosity causing the oil to move more easily to the producing wells.
797468_16_ITEM7_P58_S3	Many of Occidental's projects, including unconventional projects, rely on improving permeability to increase flow in the wells.
797468_16_ITEM7_P58_S4	In addition, some improved recovery comes from drilling infill wells that allow recovery of reserves that would not be recoverable from existing wells.
797468_16_ITEM7_P59_S0	Extensions and Discoveries Occidental also added proved reserves from extensions and discoveries, which are dependent on successful exploration and exploitation programs.
797468_16_ITEM7_P59_S1	In 2015 , extensions and discoveries added 5 million BOE related primarily to the recognition of proved developed reserves in Oman.
797468_16_ITEM7_P60_S0	Purchases of Proved Reserves Occidental continues to seek opportunities to add reserves through acquisitions when properties are available at prices it deems reasonable.
797468_16_ITEM7_P61_S0	As market conditions change, the available supply of properties may increase or decrease accordingly.
797468_16_ITEM7_P62_S0	Revisions of Previous Estimates Revisions can include upward or downward changes to previous proved reserve estimates for existing fields due to the evaluation or interpretation of geologic, production decline or operating performance data.
797468_16_ITEM7_P62_S1	In addition, product price changes affect proved reserves recorded by Occidental.
797468_16_ITEM7_P62_S2	For example, lower prices may decrease the economically recoverable reserves, particularly for domestic properties, because the reduced margin limits the expected life of the operations.
797468_16_ITEM7_P62_S3	Offsetting this effect, lower prices increase Occidental's share of proved reserves under PSCs because more oil is required to recover costs.
797468_16_ITEM7_P62_S4	Conversely, when prices rise, Occidental's share of proved reserves decreases for PSCs and economically recoverable reserves may increase for other operations.
797468_16_ITEM7_P62_S5	In 2015 , negative revisions of previous estimates of 315 million BOE were primarily price and price-related revisions associated with domestic assets.
797468_16_ITEM7_P63_S0	Reserve estimation rules require that estimated ultimate recoveries be much more likely to increase or remain constant than to decrease as changes are made due to increased availability of technical data.
797468_16_ITEM7_P64_S0	Proved Undeveloped Reserves In 2015 , Occidental had proved undeveloped reserve additions of 76 million BOE from improved recovery and extensions and discoveries.
797468_16_ITEM7_P64_S1	Of the total additions, over 80 percent represented additions from improved recovery in the Permian Basin.
797468_16_ITEM7_P64_S2	These proved undeveloped reserve additions were offset by transfers of 106 million BOE to the proved developed category as a result of the 2015 development programs.
797468_16_ITEM7_P64_S3	Permian Basin and Oman accounted for approximately 92 percent of the reserve transfers from proved undeveloped to proved developed in 2015 .
797468_16_ITEM7_P64_S4	Proved undeveloped reserves were reduced by 332 million BOE primarily due to price and price-related revisions and the sale of Williston.
797468_16_ITEM7_P64_S5	Occidental incurred approximately $1.3 billion in 2015 to convert proved undeveloped reserves to proved developed reserves.
797468_16_ITEM7_P64_S6	A substantial portion of the proved undeveloped reserves as of December 31, 2015 was the result of the development program in the Permian Basin, which represents 68 percent of total year-end proved undeveloped reserves.
797468_16_ITEM7_P65_S0	Global oversupply continues to suppress oil and gas prices significantly.
797468_16_ITEM7_P65_S1	These conditions may continue for an extended period.
797468_16_ITEM7_P65_S2	Prolonged or further declines in commodity prices could require Occidental to further reduce capital spending, potentially impacting either the quantity or the development timing of proved undeveloped reserves.
797468_16_ITEM7_P66_S0	The estimation of proved reserves is based on the requirement of reasonable certainty of economic producibility and funding commitments by Occidental to develop the reserves.
797468_16_ITEM7_P66_S1	This process involves reservoir engineers, geoscientists, planning engineers and financial analysts.
797468_16_ITEM7_P67_S0	As part of the proved reserves estimation process, all reserve volumes are estimated by a forecast of production rates, operating costs and capital expenditures.
797468_16_ITEM7_P67_S1	Price differentials between benchmark prices (the unweighted arithmetic average of the first-day-of-the-month price for each month within the year) and realized prices and specifics of each operating agreement are then used to estimate the net reserves.
797468_16_ITEM7_P68_S0	Production rate forecasts are derived by a number of methods, including estimates from decline curve analysis, type-curve analysis, material balance calculations that take into account the volumes of substances replacing the volumes produced and associated reservoir pressure changes, seismic analysis and computer simulation of the reservoir performance.
797468_16_ITEM7_P68_S1	These field-tested technologies have demonstrated reasonably certain results with consistency and repeatability in the formation being evaluated or in an analogous formation.
797468_16_ITEM7_P69_S0	Operating and capital costs are forecast using the current cost environment applied to expectations of future operating and development activities.
797468_16_ITEM7_P70_S0	Net proved developed reserves are those volumes that are expected to be recovered through existing wells with existing equipment and operating methods for which the incremental cost of any additional required investment is relatively minor.
797468_16_ITEM7_P70_S1	Net proved undeveloped reserves are those volumes that are expected to be recovered from new wells on undrilled acreage, or from existing wells where a relatively major expenditure is required for recompletion.
797468_16_ITEM7_P70_S2	The current Senior Vice President, Reserves for Oxy Oil and Gas is responsible for overseeing the preparation of reserve estimates, in compliance with U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) rules and regulations, including the internal audit and review of Occidental's oil and gas reserves data.
797468_16_ITEM7_P70_S3	The Senior Vice President has over 30 years of experience in the upstream sector of the exploration and production business, and has held various assignments in North America, Asia and Europe.
797468_16_ITEM7_P70_S4	He is a three-time past Chair of the Society of Petroleum Engineers Oil and Gas Reserves Committee.
797468_16_ITEM7_P70_S5	He is an American Association of Petroleum Geologists (AAPG) Certified Petroleum Geologist and currently serves on the AAPG Committee on Resource Evaluation.
797468_16_ITEM7_P70_S6	He is a member of the Society of Petroleum Evaluation Engineers, the Colorado School of Mines Potential Gas Committee and the UNECE Expert Group on Resource Classification.
797468_16_ITEM7_P70_S7	He is also an active member of the Joint Committee on Reserves Evaluator Training (JCORET).
797468_16_ITEM7_P71_S0	The Senior Vice President has Bachelor of Science and Master of Science degrees in geology from Emory University in Atlanta.
797468_16_ITEM7_P72_S0	Occidental has a Corporate Reserves Review Committee (Reserves Committee), consisting of senior corporate officers, to review and approve Occidental's oil and gas reserves.
797468_16_ITEM7_P72_S1	The Reserves Committee reports to the Audit Committee of Occidental's Board of Directors during the year.
797468_16_ITEM7_P73_S0	engineering consultants, to review its annual oil and gas reserve estimation processes.
797468_16_ITEM7_P73_S1	In 2015 , Ryder Scott conducted a process review of the methods and analytical procedures utilized by Occidental s engineering and geological staff for estimating the proved reserves volumes, preparing the economic evaluations and determining the reserves classifications as of December 31, 2015 , in accordance with the SEC regulatory standards.
797468_16_ITEM7_P73_S2	Ryder Scott reviewed the specific application of such methods and procedures for selected oil and gas properties considered to be a valid representation of Occidental s 2015 year-end total proved reserves portfolio.
797468_16_ITEM7_P74_S0	In 2015 , Ryder Scott reviewed approximately 19 percent of Occidental s proved oil and gas reserves.
797468_16_ITEM7_P74_S1	Since being engaged in 2003, Ryder Scott has reviewed the specific application of Occidental s reserve estimation methods and procedures for approximately 80 percent of Occidental s existing proved oil and gas reserves.
797468_16_ITEM7_P74_S2	Management retains Ryder Scott to provide objective third-party input on its methods and procedures and to gather industry information applicable to Occidental s reserve estimation and reporting process.
797468_16_ITEM7_P75_S0	Ryder Scott has not been engaged to render an opinion as to the reasonableness of reserves quantities reported by Occidental.
797468_16_ITEM7_P75_S1	Occidental has filed Ryder Scott's independent report as an exhibit to this Form 10-K. Based on its reviews, including the data, technical processes and interpretations presented by Occidental, Ryder Scott has concluded that the overall procedures and methodologies Occidental utilized in estimating the proved reserves volumes, documenting the changes in reserves from prior estimates, preparing the economic evaluations and determining the reserves classifications for the reviewed properties are appropriate for the purpose thereof and comply with current SEC regulations.
797468_16_ITEM7_P76_S0	Industry Outlook The petroleum industry is highly competitive and subject to significant volatility due to various market conditions.
797468_16_ITEM7_P76_S1	The WTI and Brent oil price indexes declined further in 2015 , closing at $37.04 per barrel and $37.28 per barrel, respectively, as of December 31, 2015 .
797468_16_ITEM7_P76_S2	Commodity prices continued their decline in early 2016.
797468_16_ITEM7_P76_S3	The WTI and Brent oil price indexes were $53.27 per barrel and $57.33 per barrel, respectively, as of December 31, 2014 .
797468_16_ITEM7_P76_S4	Oil prices will continue to be affected by: (i) global supply and demand, which are generally a function of global economic conditions, inventory levels, production disruptions, technological advances, regional market conditions and the actions of OPEC, other significant producers and governments; (ii) transportation capacity, infrastructure constraints, and cost in producing areas; (iii) currency exchange rates; and (iv) the effect of changes in these variables on market perceptions.
797468_16_ITEM7_P77_S0	NGLs prices are related to the supply and demand for the components of products making up these liquids.
797468_16_ITEM7_P77_S1	Some of them more typically correlate to the price of oil while others are affected by natural gas prices as well as the demand for certain chemical products for which they are used as feedstock.
797468_16_ITEM7_P77_S2	In addition, infrastructure constraints magnify the pricing volatility from region to region.
797468_16_ITEM7_P78_S0	Domestic natural gas prices and local differentials are strongly affected by local supply and demand fundamentals, as well as government regulations and availability of transportation capacity from producing areas.
797468_16_ITEM7_P78_S1	These and other factors make it impossible to predict the future direction of oil, NGLs and domestic gas prices reliably.
797468_16_ITEM7_P79_S0	International gas prices are generally fixed under long-term contracts.
797468_16_ITEM7_P80_S0	Occidental continues to respond to economic conditions by adjusting capital expenditures in line with current economic conditions with the goal of keeping returns well above its cost of capital.
797468_16_ITEM7_P81_S0	Despite the continued modest pace of United States economic growth, demand for domestically produced energy and feedstocks decreased slightly as the global economic slowdown broadened and the strength of the U.S. dollar hindered exports.
797468_16_ITEM7_P81_S1	Vinyls margins improved during the second half of 2015 as the cost of feedstocks, primarily ethylene and natural gas, improved significantly from 2014 levels.
797468_16_ITEM7_P82_S0	Business Review Basic Chemicals During 2015, the United States economy continued its slow recovery with full-year growth expected to be below the 2.4 percent growth rate experienced in 2014.
797468_16_ITEM7_P82_S1	The lower U.S. growth rate was reflected in lower domestic demand as the industry chlorine operating rate decreased 1 percent to 83 percent from 84 percent in 2014.
797468_16_ITEM7_P82_S2	The slightly lower operating rate resulted in only a moderate improvement in chlorine pricing.
797468_16_ITEM7_P82_S3	Exports of downstream chlorine derivatives into the vinyls chain were competitive for the balance of the year as ethylene costs decreased in line with falling energy costs.
797468_16_ITEM7_P82_S4	However, total derivative export volume was down versus 2014 as global demand softened particularly in Asia and Latin America.
797468_16_ITEM7_P82_S5	Liquid caustic soda prices experienced downward price pressure during the first three quarters of 2015 as the industry continued to absorb the additional chlor-alkali capacity that has come on line in the U.S. during the last 2 years.
797468_16_ITEM7_P82_S6	Domestic caustic soda prices rose in the fourth quarter of 2015 as the industry pushed to expand margins from historically depressed levels.
797468_16_ITEM7_P82_S7	Export demand and pricing remains under pressure due to global over capacity and lower growth in major consuming regions and the strength of the U.S. dollar impacted demand for U.S. products.
797468_16_ITEM7_P82_S8	Businesses such as calcium chloride and especially muriatic acid, were down due to substantially reduced oil and gas drilling activity and demand.
797468_16_ITEM7_P83_S0	Vinyls Industry PVC margins improved slightly in 2015 compared to 2014 as record high spot ethylene costs declined sharply throughout the year and offset declines in PVC pricing.
797468_16_ITEM7_P83_S1	Year-over-year domestic PVC demand increased only 0.9 percent due to the slow start to 2015 housing construction following extended winter conditions as well as the slower pace of growth in single family home sales.
797468_16_ITEM7_P84_S0	decreased 2.5 percent in 2015 compared to 2014.
797468_16_ITEM7_P84_S1	The PVC industry operating rate in 2015 of 83.7 percent was 0.6 percent lower than 2014 largely due to increased industry capacity coming on-line.
797468_16_ITEM7_P84_S2	Export volume remained a significant portion of PVC sales representing 30 percent of total North American producer s production.
797468_16_ITEM7_P84_S3	The U.S. ethylene cost advantage of prior years has been reduced as world oil prices continued to decline in 2015.
797468_16_ITEM7_P85_S0	In early 2014, OxyChem, through a 50/50 joint venture with Mexichem S.A.B. de C.V., broke ground on a 1.2 billion pound-per-year ethylene cracker at the OxyChem Ingleside facility.
797468_16_ITEM7_P85_S1	Construction on the ethylene cracker remains on budget and on schedule and the facility is expected to begin operating in early 2017.
797468_16_ITEM7_P86_S0	Industry Outlook Industry performance will depend on the health of the global economy, specifically in the housing, construction, automotive and durable goods markets.
797468_16_ITEM7_P86_S1	Margins also depend on market supply and demand balances and feedstock and energy prices.
797468_16_ITEM7_P87_S0	Long-term weakness in the petroleum industry may negatively affect the demand and pricing of a number of Occidental s products that are consumed by industry participants.
797468_16_ITEM7_P88_S0	Basic Chemicals Occidental expects that if the United States housing, automotive and durable goods markets continue to improve, domestic demand for basic chemical products should be moderately higher in 2016.
797468_16_ITEM7_P88_S1	Overall, the low chlor-alkali operating rates driven by capacity increases may limit significant price improvement but expected demand coupled with low energy costs should allow the margin gains secured at the end of 2015 to remain in place.
797468_16_ITEM7_P89_S0	The continued competitiveness of downstream chlorine derivatives in global markets is contingent on United States feedstock costs, primarily natural gas and ethylene, remaining favorable compared to other feedstock costs in global markets.
797468_16_ITEM7_P90_S0	Vinyls North American demand and operating rates should improve in 2016 as growth in both housing starts and commercial construction continues.
797468_16_ITEM7_P90_S1	Occidental expects U.S. export demand to improve modestly and for margins to be on par with 2015.
797468_16_ITEM7_P91_S0	MIDSTREAM AND MARKETING SEGMENT Business Environment Midstream and marketing segment earnings are affected by the performance of its marketing and trading businesses and its processing, transportation and power generation assets.
797468_16_ITEM7_P91_S1	Marketing and trading performance is affected primarily by commodity price changes and margins in oil and gas transportation and storage programs.
797468_16_ITEM7_P91_S2	Processing and transportation results are affected by the volumes that are processed and transported through the segment's plants and pipelines, as well as the margins obtained on related services.
797468_16_ITEM7_P92_S0	Pipeline Transportation Margin and cash flow from pipeline transportation operations mainly reflect volumes shipped.
797468_16_ITEM7_P93_S0	Dolphin Energy owns and operates a 230-mile-long, 48-inch-diameter natural gas pipeline (Dolphin Pipeline), which transports dry natural gas from Qatar to the UAE and Oman.
797468_16_ITEM7_P93_S1	The Dolphin Pipeline has capacity to transport up to 3.2 Bcf of natural gas per day and currently transports approximately 2.3 Bcf per day.
797468_16_ITEM7_P94_S0	Occidental owns an oil common carrier pipeline and storage system with approximately 2,900 miles of pipelines from southeast New Mexico across the Permian Basin of southwest Texas to Cushing, Oklahoma.
797468_16_ITEM7_P94_S1	The system has a current throughput capacity of about 720,000 barrels per day, 7.0 million barrels of active storage capability and 127 truck unloading facilities at various points along the system, which allow for additional volumes to be delivered into the pipeline.
797468_16_ITEM7_P95_S0	Occidental's 2015 pipeline transportation earnings declined from 2014 primarily due to lower income from its investment in Plains Pipeline as a result of Occidental's November 2014 sale of a portion of its Plains Pipeline interest.
797468_16_ITEM7_P96_S0	Gas Processing Plants and CO 2 Fields and Facilities Occidental processes its and third-party domestic wet gas to extract NGLs and other gas byproducts, including CO 2 , and delivers dry gas to pipelines.
797468_16_ITEM7_P97_S0	Margins primarily result from the difference between inlet costs of wet gas and market prices for NGLs.
797468_16_ITEM7_P98_S0	Occidental, together with ADNOC, completed the Al Hosn gas processing facilities in Abu Dhabi at the end of 2014 and became fully operational in 2015.
797468_16_ITEM7_P98_S1	The Al Hosn gas processing facilities are designed to process 1.0 bcf per day of natural gas and separate it into sales gas, condensate, NGLs and sulfur.
797468_16_ITEM7_P99_S0	The Al Hosn gas processing facilities include facilities to extract sulfur from natural gas and process it for sale.
797468_16_ITEM7_P99_S1	The facility produces approximately 8,700 tons per day of sulfur, of which Occidental's share is approximately 3,500 tons of sulfur per day.
797468_16_ITEM7_P100_S0	Occidental relies upon several sources to ensure an adequate supply of CO 2 for its Permian EOR operations, including the Occidental operated Bravo Dome field in northeastern New Mexico and additional supplies from methane fields in the southwestern Permian Basin.
797468_16_ITEM7_P100_S1	Occidental s Century Plant in Pecos County, Texas, further expands its EOR infrastructure in the Permian Basin.
797468_16_ITEM7_P100_S2	The plant processes natural gas with high CO 2 content, resulting in methane gas for the market as well as a major source of CO 2 for our Permian operations.
797468_16_ITEM7_P100_S3	Occidental s 2015 earnings from these operations decreased compared to 2014 due to lower realized NGL prices, partially offset by the commencement of Al Hosn sulfur sales.
797468_16_ITEM7_P101_S0	Power Generation Facilities Earnings from power and steam generation facilities are derived from sales to affiliates and third parties.
797468_16_ITEM7_P101_S1	The decrease in earnings in 2015 compared to 2014 was due to lower margins in lower spark spreads and decreased production resulting from increased planned outages.
797468_16_ITEM7_P102_S0	Marketing The marketing group markets substantially all of Occidental s oil, NGLs and gas production, and trades around its assets, including its transportation and storage capacity.
797468_16_ITEM7_P103_S0	Occidental s third-party marketing and trading activities focus on purchasing oil, NGLs and gas for resale from parties whose oil and gas supply is located near its transportation and storage assets.
797468_16_ITEM7_P103_S1	These purchases allow Occidental to aggregate volumes to better utilize and optimize its assets.
797468_16_ITEM7_P104_S0	Marketing performance in 2015 declined compared to 2014 due to the narrowing of the Midland to Gulf Coast oil price differentials.
797468_16_ITEM7_P105_S0	Industry Outlook The pipeline transportation and power generation businesses are expected to remain relatively stable.
797468_16_ITEM7_P105_S1	The gas processing plant operations could have volatile results depending mostly on NGLs prices, which cannot reasonably be predicted.
797468_16_ITEM7_P105_S2	Generally, higher NGLs prices result in higher profitability.
797468_16_ITEM7_P106_S0	The marketing business in isolation can be volatile in periods of severe price swings.
797468_16_ITEM7_P106_S1	Occidental continues to actively focus on marketing its commodity production to generate maximum value for its stakeholders.
797468_16_ITEM7_P107_S0	Segment earnings exclude income taxes, interest income, interest expense, environmental remediation expenses, unallocated corporate expenses and discontinued operations, but include gains and losses from dispositions of segment assets and income from the segments' equity investments.
797468_16_ITEM7_P108_S0	Seasonality is not a primary driver of changes in Occidental's consolidated quarterly earnings during the year.
