797468_18_ITEM7_P56_S1	Changes in reserves were as follows:
797468_18_ITEM7_P57_S0	Occidental's ability to add reserves, other than through purchases, depends on the success of improved recovery, extension and discovery projects, each of which depends on reservoir characteristics, technology improvements and oil and natural gas prices, as well as capital and operating costs.
797468_18_ITEM7_P57_S1	Many of these factors are outside management s control, and may negatively or positively affect Occidental's reserves.
797468_18_ITEM7_P58_S0	Revisions of Previous Estimates Revisions can include upward or downward changes to previous proved reserve estimates for existing fields due to the evaluation or interpretation of geologic, production decline or operating performance data.
797468_18_ITEM7_P58_S1	In addition, product price changes affect proved reserves recorded by Occidental.
797468_18_ITEM7_P58_S2	For example, lower prices may decrease the economically recoverable reserves, particularly for domestic properties, because the reduced margin limits the expected life of the operations.
797468_18_ITEM7_P58_S3	Offsetting this effect, lower prices increase Occidental's share of proved reserves under PSCs because more oil is required to recover costs.
797468_18_ITEM7_P58_S4	Conversely, when prices rise, Occidental's share of proved reserves decreases for PSCs and economically recoverable reserves may increase for other operations.
797468_18_ITEM7_P59_S0	In 2017, Occidental had positive revisions of 151 million BOE, mainly in the Permian Basin and Oman.
797468_18_ITEM7_P60_S0	Reserve estimation rules require that estimated ultimate recoveries be much more likely to increase or remain constant than to decrease, as changes are made due to increased availability of technical data.
797468_18_ITEM7_P61_S0	In 2017 , Occidental added proved reserves of 201 million BOE mainly associated with the Permian Basin and UAE.
797468_18_ITEM7_P61_S1	These properties comprise both conventional projects, which are characterized by the deployment of EOR development methods, largely employing application of CO 2 flood, waterflood or steam flood, and unconventional projects.
797468_18_ITEM7_P61_S2	These types of conventional EOR development methods can be applied through existing wells, though additional drilling is frequently required to fully optimize the development configuration.
797468_18_ITEM7_P62_S0	Waterflooding is the technique of injecting water into the formation to displace the oil to the offsetting oil production wells.
797468_18_ITEM7_P63_S0	either CO 2 or steam and other economic factors.
797468_18_ITEM7_P63_S1	Both techniques work similarly to lower viscosity causing the oil to move more easily to the producing wells.
797468_18_ITEM7_P63_S2	Many of Occidental's projects, including unconventional projects, rely on improving permeability to increase flow in the wells.
797468_18_ITEM7_P63_S3	In addition, some improved recovery comes from drilling infill wells that allow recovery of reserves that would not be recoverable from existing wells.

797468_18_ITEM7_P73_S0	Reserves Evaluation and Review Process Occidental's estimates of proved reserves and associated future net cash flows as of December 31, 2017 , were made by Occidental s technical personnel and are the responsibility of management.
797468_18_ITEM7_P73_S1	The estimation of proved reserves is based on the requirement of reasonable certainty of economic producibility and funding commitments by Occidental to develop the reserves.
797468_18_ITEM7_P73_S2	This process involves reservoir engineers, geoscientists, planning engineers and financial analysts.
797468_18_ITEM7_P74_S0	As part of the proved reserves estimation process, all reserve volumes are estimated by a forecast of production rates, operating costs and capital expenditures.
797468_18_ITEM7_P74_S1	Price differentials between benchmark prices (the unweighted arithmetic average of the first-day-of-the-month price for each month within the year) and realized prices and specifics of each operating agreement are then used to estimate the net reserves.
797468_18_ITEM7_P75_S0	Production rate forecasts are derived by a number of methods, including estimates from decline curve analysis, type curve analysis, material balance calculations that take into account the volumes of substances replacing the volumes produced, and associated reservoir pressure changes, seismic analysis and computer simulation of the reservoir performance.
797468_18_ITEM7_P75_S1	These field-tested technologies have demonstrated reasonably certain results with consistency and repeatability in the formation being evaluated or in an analogous formation.
797468_18_ITEM7_P76_S0	Operating and capital costs are forecast using the current cost environment applied to expectations of future operating and development activities.
797468_18_ITEM7_P77_S0	Net proved developed reserves are those volumes that are expected to be recovered through existing wells with existing equipment and operating methods for which the incremental cost of any additional required investment is relatively minor.
797468_18_ITEM7_P77_S1	Net proved undeveloped reserves are those volumes that are expected to be recovered from new wells on undrilled acreage, or from existing wells where a relatively major expenditure is required for recompletion.
797468_18_ITEM7_P77_S2	Proved undeveloped reserves are supported by a five-year, detailed, field-level development plan, which includes the timing, location and capital commitment of the wells to be drilled.
797468_18_ITEM7_P77_S3	The development plan is reviewed and approved annually by senior management and technical personnel.
797468_18_ITEM7_P77_S4	Annually a detailed review is performed by Occidental s Worldwide Reserves Group and its technical personnel on a lease-by-lease basis to assess whether proved undeveloped reserves are being converted on a timely basis within five years from the initial disclosure date.
797468_18_ITEM7_P78_S0	undeveloped reserves to proved developed reserves are reviewed by senior management to determine if the remaining reserves will be developed in a timely manner and has sufficient capital committed in the development plan.
797468_18_ITEM7_P78_S1	Only proved undeveloped reserves that are reasonably certain to be drilled within five years of booking and are supported by a final investment decision to drill them are included in the development plan.
797468_18_ITEM7_P78_S2	A portion of the proved developed reserves associated with international operations are expected to be developed beyond the five years and are tied to approved long-term development plans.
797468_18_ITEM7_P79_S0	The current Senior Vice President, Reserves for Oxy Oil and Gas is responsible for overseeing the preparation of reserve estimates, in compliance with U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) rules and regulations, including the internal audit and review of Occidental's oil and gas reserves data.
797468_18_ITEM7_P79_S1	He has over 30 years of experience in the upstream sector of the exploration and production business, and has held various assignments in North America, Asia and Europe.
797468_18_ITEM7_P79_S2	He is a three-time past Chair of the Society of Petroleum Engineers Oil and Gas Reserves Committee.
797468_18_ITEM7_P79_S3	He is an American Association of Petroleum Geologists (AAPG) Certified Petroleum Geologist and currently serves on the AAPG Committee on Resource Evaluation.
797468_18_ITEM7_P79_S4	He is a member of the Society of Petroleum Evaluation Engineers, the Colorado School of Mines Potential Gas Committee and the UNECE Expert Group on Resource Classification.
797468_18_ITEM7_P80_S0	He has Bachelor of Science and Master of Science degrees in geology from Emory University in Atlanta.

797468_18_ITEM7_P81_S1	The Reserves Committee reports to the Audit Committee of Occidental's Board of Directors during the year.
797468_18_ITEM7_P82_S0	Since 2003, Occidental has retained Ryder Scott Company, L.P. (Ryder Scott), independent petroleum engineering consultants, to review its annual oil and gas reserve estimation processes.
797468_18_ITEM7_P82_S1	In 2017 , Ryder Scott conducted a process review of the methods and analytical procedures utilized by Occidental s engineering and geological staff for estimating the proved reserves volumes, preparing the economic evaluations and determining the reserves classifications as of December 31, 2017 , in accordance with the SEC regulatory standards.
797468_18_ITEM7_P82_S2	Ryder Scott reviewed the specific application of such methods and procedures for selected oil and gas properties considered to be a valid representation of Occidental s 2017 year-end total proved reserves portfolio.
797468_18_ITEM7_P82_S3	In 2017 , Ryder Scott reviewed approximately 20 percent of Occidental s proved oil and gas reserves.
797468_18_ITEM7_P83_S0	Since being engaged in 2003, Ryder Scott has reviewed the specific application of Occidental s reserve estimation methods and procedures for approximately 80 percent of Occidental s existing proved oil and gas reserves.
797468_18_ITEM7_P83_S1	Management retains Ryder Scott to provide objective third-party input on its methods and procedures and to gather industry information applicable to Occidental s reserve estimation and reporting process.
797468_18_ITEM7_P84_S0	Occidental has filed Ryder Scott's independent report as an exhibit to this Form 10-K. Based on its reviews, including the data, technical processes and interpretations presented by Occidental, Ryder Scott has concluded that the overall procedures and methodologies Occidental utilized in estimating the proved reserves volumes, documenting the changes in reserves from prior estimates, preparing the economic evaluations and determining the reserves classifications for the reviewed properties are appropriate for the purpose thereof and comply with current SEC regulations.
797468_18_ITEM7_P85_S0	Industry Outlook The petroleum industry is highly competitive and subject to significant volatility due to various market conditions.
797468_18_ITEM7_P85_S1	WTI and Brent oil price indexes for 2017 were above the 2016 index prices closing at $60.42 per barrel and $66.87 per barrel, respectively, as of December 31, 2017 .
797468_18_ITEM7_P85_S2	Commodity prices remained relatively constant in 2017 and started to increase in the latter part of the fourth quarter.
797468_18_ITEM7_P85_S3	Oil prices will continue to be affected by: (i) global supply and demand, which are generally a function of global economic conditions, inventory levels, production disruptions, technological advances, regional market conditions and the actions of OPEC, other significant producers and governments; (ii) transportation capacity, infrastructure constraints, and costs in producing areas; (iii) currency exchange rates; and (iv) the effect of changes in these variables on market perceptions.
797468_18_ITEM7_P86_S0	NGLs prices are related to the supply and demand for the components of products making up these liquids.
797468_18_ITEM7_P86_S1	Some of them more typically correlate to the price of oil while others are affected by natural gas prices as well as the demand for certain chemical products for which they are used as feedstock.
797468_18_ITEM7_P86_S2	In addition, infrastructure constraints magnify the pricing volatility from region to region.
797468_18_ITEM7_P87_S0	Domestic natural gas prices and local differentials are strongly affected by local supply and demand fundamentals, as well as government regulations and availability of transportation capacity from producing areas.
797468_18_ITEM7_P87_S1	These and other factors make it difficult to predict the future direction of oil, NGLs and domestic gas prices reliably.
797468_18_ITEM7_P87_S2	For purposes of the current capital plan, Occidental anticipates 2018 oil prices to be higher than average 2017 oil prices.
797468_18_ITEM7_P88_S0	International gas prices are generally fixed under long-term contracts.
797468_18_ITEM7_P89_S0	Occidental continues to respond to economic conditions by adjusting capital expenditures in line with current economic conditions with the goal of keeping returns well above its cost of capital.
797468_18_ITEM7_P90_S0	In 2017, U.S. economic growth surpassed that of 2016 and was supported by growing demand for domestically produced energy and feedstocks, even though natural gas and ethylene pricing was higher on average than in 2016.
797468_18_ITEM7_P90_S1	Hurricane Harvey impacted the ethylene market in the second half of 2017 and ethylene pricing on average ended the year slightly higher than 2016.
797468_18_ITEM7_P91_S0	resulted in higher margins, while PVC margins slightly improved as prices kept up with raw material costs.

797468_18_ITEM7_P92_S1	The higher U.S. growth rate bolstered domestic demand as the 2017 industry chlorine operating rate increased by 4 percent, to 88 percent, resulting in an improvement in chlorine pricing in the second half of 2017.
797468_18_ITEM7_P92_S2	Exports of downstream chlorine derivatives into the vinyls chain were stable in 2017 as U.S. ethylene and energy costs remained advantaged over global pricing.
797468_18_ITEM7_P92_S3	Liquid caustic soda prices improved both domestically and globally in 2017, as increased demand and tighter supply supported the higher pricing.

797468_18_ITEM7_P93_S2	Export volume remains a significant portion of PVC sales, representing over 30 percent of total North American producer s production.
797468_18_ITEM7_P93_S3	PVC industry operating rates decreased less than one percent compared to 2016, despite impact from Hurricane Harvey.
797468_18_ITEM7_P93_S4	Industry PVC margins slightly improved in 2017, as PVC pricing kept pace with higher ethylene cost.
797468_18_ITEM7_P94_S0	Industry Outlook I ndustry performance will depend on the health of the global economy, specifically in the housing, construction, automotive and durable goods markets.
797468_18_ITEM7_P94_S1	Margins also depend on market supply-and-demand balances and feedstock and energy prices.
797468_18_ITEM7_P95_S0	Strengthening in the petroleum industry may positively affect the demand and pricing of a number of Occidental s products that are consumed by industry participants.
797468_18_ITEM7_P95_S1	U.S. commodity export markets will continue to be impacted by the relative strength of the U.S. dollar, which is anticipated to be relatively neutral in 2018.
797468_18_ITEM7_P96_S0	Basic Chemicals Continued improvement in the United States housing, automotive and durable goods markets should drive a moderate increase in domestic demand for basic chemical products in 2018.
797468_18_ITEM7_P96_S1	Export demand for caustic is also expected to remain firm in 2018.
797468_18_ITEM7_P96_S2	Chlor-alkali operating rates should improve moderately with higher demand and continued competitive energy and raw material pricing as compared to global feedstock costs.
797468_18_ITEM7_P96_S3	Businesses such as calcium chloride and muriatic acid continue to improve as oil and gas drilling activity increases in the U.S., which is expected to continue in 2018.
797468_18_ITEM7_P97_S0	Vinyls North American demand should continue to show improvement in 2018 over 2017 levels as growth in construction spending continues with further upside potential driven by new infrastructure projects.
797468_18_ITEM7_P98_S0	American operating rates are expected to remain relatively flat with 2017 but margins should improve as demand in the United States strengthens.
797468_18_ITEM7_P99_S0	MIDSTREAM AND MARKETING SEGMENT Business Environment Midstream and marketing segment earnings are affected by the performance of its various businesses including its gas processing, transportation, power-generation assets, and storage facilities and terminal business.
797468_18_ITEM7_P100_S0	The marketing business aggregates markets, and stores Occidental's and third-party volumes.
797468_18_ITEM7_P101_S0	Marketing performance is affected primarily by commodity price changes and margins in oil and gas transportation and storage programs.
797468_18_ITEM7_P101_S1	Gas processing and transportation results are affected by the volumes that are processed and transported through the segment's plants and pipelines, as well as the margins obtained on related services.
797468_18_ITEM7_P101_S2	The midstream and marketing segment earnings in 2017 were significantly higher than those in 2016 primarily due to improved Permian to Gulf Coast price differentials, higher plant income due to higher NGL prices and higher income from a full year of operating the Ingleside Crude Terminal.
797468_18_ITEM7_P102_S0	Business Review Pipeline and Gathering Systems and Transportation Margin and cash flow from pipeline transportation operations mainly reflect volumes shipped.
797468_18_ITEM7_P103_S0	Dolphin Energy owns and operates a 230-mile-long, 48-inch-diameter natural gas pipeline (Dolphin Pipeline), which transports dry natural gas from Qatar to the UAE and Oman.
797468_18_ITEM7_P103_S1	The Dolphin Pipeline contributes significantly to Occidental's pipeline transportation results through Occidental's 24.5-percent interest in Dolphin Energy.
797468_18_ITEM7_P103_S2	The Dolphin Pipeline has capacity to transport up to 3.2 Bcf of natural gas per day and currently transports approximately 2.2 Bcf per day, and up to 2.5 Bcf per day in the summer.
797468_18_ITEM7_P104_S0	Occidental owns an oil common carrier pipeline and storage system with approximately 2,950 miles of pipelines from southeast New Mexico across the Permian Basin in West Texas to Cushing, Oklahoma.
797468_18_ITEM7_P104_S1	The system has a current throughput capacity of about 720,000 barrels per day, 7.1 million barrels of active storage capability and 128 truck unloading facilities at various points along the system, which allow for additional volumes to be delivered into the pipeline.
797468_18_ITEM7_P104_S2	In 2017, Occidental expanded its oil pipeline system in New Mexico by an additional 50 miles.
797468_18_ITEM7_P104_S3	Occidental's 2017 pipeline transportation earnings increased from 2016 due to higher throughput volumes and improved margins.
797468_18_ITEM7_P105_S0	Gas Processing Plants and CO 2 Fields and Facilities Occidental processes its and third-party domestic wet gas to extract NGLs and other gas byproducts, including CO 2 , and delivers dry gas to pipelines.
797468_18_ITEM7_P106_S0	Margins primarily result from the difference between inlet costs of wet gas and market prices for NGLs.
797468_18_ITEM7_P106_S1	Occidental s 2017 earnings from these operations increased compared to 2016 due to higher throughput volumes and higher realized NGL pricing.
797468_18_ITEM7_P107_S0	natural gas and separate it into sales gas, condensate, NGLs and sulfur.
797468_18_ITEM7_P107_S1	The facilities produce approximately 10,500 tons per day of sulfur, of which approximately 4,200 tons is Occidental's share.
797468_18_ITEM7_P107_S2	Al Hosn Gas facilities generate revenues from gas processing fees and the sale of sulfur.
797468_18_ITEM7_P107_S3	The increase in 2017 earnings compared to 2016 was primarily due to higher throughput volumes and higher sulfur pricing.
797468_18_ITEM7_P108_S0	Power Generation Facilities Earnings from power and steam generation facilities are derived from sales to affiliates and third parties.
797468_18_ITEM7_P108_S1	The decrease in earnings in 2017 compared to 2016 was a result of lower production due to longer outages and lower ancillary sales.
797468_18_ITEM7_P109_S0	Storage Facilities and Terminal Assets Occidental owns the Oxy Ingleside Energy Center, which includes the Ingleside Crude Terminal, a crude oil storage and export terminal located in the Port of Corpus Christi in Ingleside, Texas.
797468_18_ITEM7_P109_S1	The facility has a competitive advantage over other similarly situated export terminals, with a location near port entry, access to deep water, industry-leading loading rates and reduced lay times while berthed.
797468_18_ITEM7_P109_S2	The facility has over 300,000 barrels per day of throughput capacity, along with 2.1 million barrels of storage and three loading berths with 80,000 barrels per hour loading capability.
797468_18_ITEM7_P109_S3	The terminal is currently capable of loading articulated tug barges (ATB), medium range (MR), Aframax and Suezmax size vessels.
797468_18_ITEM7_P109_S4	In 2017, Occidental became the largest exporter of Permian light sweet crude from the United States (U.S.) Gulf Coast.
797468_18_ITEM7_P109_S5	The export market for crude has developed since the lifting of the export ban in 2016.
797468_18_ITEM7_P109_S6	While U.S. producers have increased production of light crude, U.S. refineries are constrained in their ability to process incremental volumes of light crude without significant incremental capital investment, necessitating exports to international markets.
797468_18_ITEM7_P109_S7	In response to the increase in Permian production and the need to export these barrels, Occidental is expanding its terminal to approximately 750,000 barrels per day of capacity and 6.8 million barrels of storage which will be operational by the end of 2019.
797468_18_ITEM7_P109_S8	Occidental is also expanding the facility to be capable of loading VLCC size vessels by the fourth quarter of 2018.
797468_18_ITEM7_P110_S0	Marketing The marketing group markets substantially all of Occidental s oil, NGLs and gas production, as well as trades around its assets, including its own and third-party transportation and storage capacity.
797468_18_ITEM7_P111_S0	Occidental s third-party marketing activities focus on purchasing oil, NGLs and gas for resale from parties whose oil and gas supply is located near its transportation and storage assets.
797468_18_ITEM7_P111_S1	These purchases allow Occidental to aggregate volumes to better utilize and optimize its assets.
797468_18_ITEM7_P111_S2	Marketing performance in 2017 improved compared to 2016 due to favorable Permian-to-Gulf Coast crude oil price differentials and higher marketing volumes.
797468_18_ITEM7_P112_S0	Industry Outlook The pipeline transportation and power generation businesses are expected to remain relatively stable.
797468_18_ITEM7_P112_S1	Marketing results can have significant volatile results depending on significant price swings, as well as Permian-to-Gulf Coast crude oil differentials.
797468_18_ITEM7_P112_S2	The gas processing plant operations could have volatile results depending on NGLs prices.
797468_18_ITEM7_P112_S3	Generally, higher NGLs prices result in higher profitability.

797468_18_ITEM7_P129_S0	TAXES On December 22, 2017, Tax Reform was enacted which made significant changes to the U.S. federal income tax law, including lowering the federal corporate income tax rate from 35 percent to 21 percent, repealing the corporate AMT and mandating a deemed repatriation of accumulated earnings and profits of U.S.-owned foreign corporations.
797468_18_ITEM7_P129_S1	Occidental recorded the effects of the changes in the tax law for which the accounting was complete.
797468_18_ITEM7_P129_S2	In accordance with the guidance from the SEC, Occidental recorded a provisional estimate for the federal and state tax associated with the mandatory deemed repatriation and the resulting impact to the net federal deferred tax liability.
797468_18_ITEM7_P130_S0	Tax Reform resulted in a one-time non-cash gain of $583 million due to the remeasurement of net deferred tax liabilities to the new federal corporate income tax rate.
797468_18_ITEM7_P130_S1	Occidental recognized a noncurrent receivable of $221 million for its corporate AMT credit carryforwards.
797468_18_ITEM7_P130_S2	The tax impact of Occidental's deemed repatriation of accumulated earnings was fully offset by foreign tax credits.
797468_18_ITEM7_P130_S3	At December 31, 2017, Occidental reversed its indefinite re-investment assertion with regards to its investments in foreign subsidiaries and as a result, a deferred foreign tax liability of $99 million was recorded.
797468_18_ITEM7_P131_S0	The ultimate impact of Tax Reform may differ from Occidental s estimates due to changes in interpretations and assumptions as well as additional regulatory guidance.
797468_18_ITEM7_P131_S1	Occidental will adjust provisional amounts as updated information is evaluated.

797468_18_ITEM7_P179_S1	The laws that require or address environmental remediation, including CERCLA and similar federal, state, local and foreign laws, may apply retroactively and regardless of fault, the legality of the original activities or the current ownership or control of sites.

797468_18_ITEM7_P185_S0	Maxus Environmental Sites When Occidental acquired Diamond Shamrock Chemicals Company (DSCC) in 1986, Maxus Energy Corporation (Maxus), a subsidiary of YPF S.A. (YPF), agreed to indemnify Occidental for a number of environmental sites, including the Diamond Alkali Superfund Site (Site) along a portion of the Passaic River.

797468_18_ITEM7_P186_S1	Prior to filing for bankruptcy, Maxus defended and indemnified Occidental in connection with clean-up and other costs associated with the sites subject to the indemnity, including the Site.

797468_18_ITEM7_P187_S1	The ROD does not address any potential remedial action for the upper nine miles of the Lower Passaic River or Newark Bay.
797468_18_ITEM7_P188_S0	design of the proposed clean-up plan outlined in the ROD at an estimated cost of $165 million.
797468_18_ITEM7_P188_S1	The EPA announced that it will pursue similar agreements with other potentially responsible parties.
797468_18_ITEM7_P189_S0	Occidental has accrued a reserve relating to its estimated allocable share of the costs to perform the design and the remediation called for in the AOC and the ROD, as well as for certain other Maxus-indemnified sites.
797468_18_ITEM7_P189_S1	Occidental's accrued estimated environmental reserve does not consider any recoveries for indemnified costs.
797468_18_ITEM7_P189_S2	Occidental s ultimate share of this liability may be higher or lower than the reserved amount, and is subject to final design plans and the resolution of Occidental's allocable share with other potentially responsible parties.
797468_18_ITEM7_P189_S3	Occidental continues to evaluate the costs to be incurred to comply with the AOC, the ROD and to perform remediation at other Maxus-indemnified sites in light of the Maxus bankruptcy and the share of ultimate liability of other potentially responsible parties.

797468_18_ITEM7_P189_S5	In July 2017, the court-approved Plan became final and the trust became effective.

797468_18_ITEM7_P195_S0	CRITICAL ACCOUNTING POLICIES AND ESTIMATES The process of preparing financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles requires Occidental's management to make informed estimates and judgments regarding certain items and transactions.
797468_18_ITEM7_P195_S1	Changes in facts and circumstances or discovery of new information may result in revised estimates and judgments, and actual results may differ from these estimates upon settlement but generally not by material amounts.
797468_18_ITEM7_P195_S2	There has been no material change to Occidental's critical accounting policies over the past three years.
797468_18_ITEM7_P195_S3	The selection and development of these policies and estimates have been discussed with the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors.
797468_18_ITEM7_P195_S4	Occidental considers the following to be its most critical accounting policies and estimates that involve management's judgment.
797468_18_ITEM7_P196_S0	The carrying value of Occidental s PP E represents the cost incurred to acquire or develop the asset, including any asset retirement obligations and capitalized interest, net of accumulated depreciation, depletion, and amortization (DD A) and any impairment charges.
797468_18_ITEM7_P196_S1	For assets acquired, PP E cost is based on fair values at the acquisition date.
797468_18_ITEM7_P197_S0	Asset retirement obligations and interest costs incurred in connection with qualifying capital expenditures are capitalized and amortized over the lives of the related assets.
797468_18_ITEM7_P198_S0	Occidental uses the successful efforts method to account for its oil and gas properties.
797468_18_ITEM7_P198_S1	Under this method, Occidental capitalizes costs of acquiring properties, costs of drilling successful exploration wells, and development costs.
797468_18_ITEM7_P198_S2	The costs of exploratory wells are initially capitalized pending a determination of whether proved reserves have been found.
797468_18_ITEM7_P198_S3	If proved reserves have been found, the costs of exploratory wells remain capitalized.
797468_18_ITEM7_P198_S4	Otherwise, Occidental charges the costs of the related wells to expense.
797468_18_ITEM7_P199_S0	In some cases, a determination of proved reserves cannot be made at the completion of drilling, requiring additional testing and evaluation of the wells.
797468_18_ITEM7_P199_S1	Occidental generally expenses the costs of such exploratory wells if a determination of proved reserves has not been made within a 12-month period after drilling is complete.
797468_18_ITEM7_P199_S2	Occidental expenses annual lease rentals, the costs of injectants used in production, and geological, geophysical and seismic costs as incurred.
797468_18_ITEM7_P200_S0	Occidental determines depreciation and depletion of oil and gas producing properties by the unit-of-production method.
797468_18_ITEM7_P200_S1	It amortizes acquisition costs over total proved reserves and capitalized development and successful exploration costs over proved developed reserves.
797468_18_ITEM7_P201_S0	data, can be estimated with reasonable certainty to be economically producible from a given date forward, from known reservoirs, and under existing economic conditions, operating methods, and government regulations prior to the time at which contracts providing the right to operate expire, unless evidence indicates that renewal is reasonably certain, regardless of whether deterministic or probabilistic methods are used for the estimation.
797468_18_ITEM7_P202_S0	Occidental has no proved oil and gas reserves for which the determination of economic producibility is subject to the completion of major additional capital expenditures.
797468_18_ITEM7_P203_S0	Several factors could change Occidental s proved oil and gas reserves.
797468_18_ITEM7_P203_S1	For example, Occidental receives a share of production from PSCs to recover its costs and generally an additional share for profit.
797468_18_ITEM7_P203_S2	Occidental s share of production and reserves from these contracts decreases when product prices rise and increases when prices decline.
797468_18_ITEM7_P203_S3	Overall, Occidental s net economic benefit from these contracts is greater at higher product prices.
797468_18_ITEM7_P203_S4	In other cases, particularly with long-lived properties, lower product prices may lead to a situation where production of a portion of proved reserves becomes uneconomical.
797468_18_ITEM7_P203_S5	For such properties, higher product prices typically result in additional reserves becoming economical.
797468_18_ITEM7_P203_S6	Estimation of future production and development costs is also subject to change partially due to factors beyond Occidental's control, such as energy costs and inflation or deflation of oil field service costs.
797468_18_ITEM7_P203_S7	These factors, in turn, could lead to changes in the quantity of proved reserves.
797468_18_ITEM7_P203_S8	Additional factors that could result in a change of proved reserves include production decline rates and operating performance differing from those estimated when the proved reserves were initially recorded.
797468_18_ITEM7_P203_S9	Additionally, Occidental performs impairment tests with respect to its proved properties whenever events or circumstances indicate that the carrying value of property may not be recoverable.
797468_18_ITEM7_P203_S10	If there is an indication the carrying amount of the asset may not be recovered due to declines in current and forward prices, significant changes in reserve estimates, changes in management's plans, or other significant events, management will evaluate the property for impairment.
797468_18_ITEM7_P203_S11	Under the successful efforts method, if the sum of the undiscounted cash flows is less than the carrying value of the proved property, the carrying value is reduced to estimated fair value and reported as an impairment charge in the period.
797468_18_ITEM7_P204_S0	Individual proved properties are grouped for impairment purposes at the lowest level for which there are identifiable cash flows.
797468_18_ITEM7_P204_S1	The fair value of impaired assets is typically determined based on the present value of expected future cash flows using discount rates believed to be consistent with those used by market participants.
797468_18_ITEM7_P205_S0	The impairment test incorporates a number of assumptions involving expectations of future cash flows which can change significantly over time.
797468_18_ITEM7_P205_S1	These assumptions include estimates of future product prices, contractual prices, estimates of risk-adjusted oil and gas reserves and estimates of future operating and development costs.
797468_18_ITEM7_P205_S2	It is reasonably possible that prolonged declines in commodity prices, reduced capital spending in response to lower prices or increases in operating costs could result in additional impairments.
797468_18_ITEM7_P206_S0	For impairment testing, unless prices were contractually fixed, Occidental used observable forward strip prices for oil and natural gas prices when projecting future cash flows.
797468_18_ITEM7_P207_S0	Prices are held constant for periods beyond those covered by forward strip prices.
797468_18_ITEM7_P208_S0	Future operating and development costs were estimated using the current cost environment applied to expectations of future operating and development activities to develop and produce oil and gas reserves.
797468_18_ITEM7_P208_S1	Market prices for crude oil, natural gas and NGLs have been volatile and may continue to be volatile in the future.
797468_18_ITEM7_P208_S2	Current market fundamentals indicate improved prices for crude oil, natural gas and NGLs in 2018; however, changes in global supply and demand, transportation capacity, currency exchange rates, and applicable laws and regulations, and the effect of changes in these variables on market perceptions could impact current forecasts.
797468_18_ITEM7_P209_S0	Future fluctuations in commodity prices could result in estimates of future cash flows to vary significantly.
797468_18_ITEM7_P209_S1	The most significant ongoing financial statement effect from a change in Occidental's oil and gas reserves or impairment of its proved properties would be to the DD A rate.
797468_18_ITEM7_P209_S2	For example, a 5 percent increase or decrease in the amount of oil and gas reserves would change the DD A rate by approximately $0.55 per barrel, which would increase or decrease pre-tax income by approximately $120 million annually at current production rates.
797468_18_ITEM7_P210_S0	A portion of the carrying value of Occidental s oil and gas properties is attributable to unproved properties.
797468_18_ITEM7_P210_S1	Net capitalized costs attributable to unproved properties were $1.0 billion and $1.4 billion at December 31, 2017 and 2016, respectively.
797468_18_ITEM7_P210_S2	The unproved amounts are not subject to DD A until they are classified as proved properties.
797468_18_ITEM7_P210_S3	Capitalized costs attributable to the properties become subject to DD A when proved reserves are assigned to the property.
797468_18_ITEM7_P210_S4	If the exploration efforts are unsuccessful, or management decides not to pursue development of these properties as a result of lower commodity prices, higher development and operating costs, contractual conditions or other factors, the capitalized costs of the related properties would be expensed.
797468_18_ITEM7_P210_S5	The timing of any writedowns of these unproved properties, if warranted, depends upon management's plans, the nature, timing and extent of future exploration and development activities and their results.
797468_18_ITEM7_P210_S6	Occidental believes its current plans and exploration and development efforts will allow it to realize its unproved property balance.
797468_18_ITEM7_P211_S0	Chemical Assets Occidental's chemical assets are depreciated using either the unit-of-production or the straight-line method, based upon the estimated useful lives of the facilities.
797468_18_ITEM7_P211_S1	The estimated useful lives of Occidental s chemical assets, which range from three years to 50 years, are also used for impairment tests.
797468_18_ITEM7_P211_S2	The estimated useful lives for the chemical facilities are based on the assumption that Occidental will provide an appropriate level of annual expenditures to ensure productive capacity is sustained.
797468_18_ITEM7_P211_S3	Such expenditures consist of ongoing routine repairs and maintenance, as well as planned major maintenance activities (PMMA).
797468_18_ITEM7_P211_S4	Ongoing routine repairs and maintenance expenditures are expensed as incurred.
797468_18_ITEM7_P212_S0	PMMA costs are capitalized and amortized over the period until the next planned overhaul.
797468_18_ITEM7_P212_S1	Additionally, Occidental incurs capital expenditures that extend the remaining useful lives of existing assets, increase their capacity or operating efficiency beyond the original specification or add value through modification for a different use.
797468_18_ITEM7_P212_S2	These capital expenditures are not considered in the initial determination of the useful lives of these assets at the time they are placed into service.
797468_18_ITEM7_P212_S3	The resulting revision, if any, of the asset s estimated useful life is measured and accounted for prospectively.
797468_18_ITEM7_P212_S4	Without these continued expenditures, the useful lives of these assets could decrease significantly.
797468_18_ITEM7_P212_S5	Other factors that could change the estimated useful lives of Occidental s chemical assets include sustained higher or lower product prices, which are particularly affected by both domestic and foreign competition, demand, feedstock costs, energy prices, environmental regulations and technological changes.
797468_18_ITEM7_P213_S0	Occidental performs impairment tests on its chemical assets whenever events or changes in circumstances lead to a reduction in the estimated useful lives or estimated future cash flows that would indicate that the carrying amount may not be recoverable, or when management s plans change with respect to those assets.
797468_18_ITEM7_P213_S1	Any impairment loss would be calculated as the excess of the asset's net book value over its estimated fair value.
797468_18_ITEM7_P213_S2	Occidental's net PP E for the chemical segment is approximately $2.4 billion and its DD A expense for 2018 is expected to be approximately $350 million.
797468_18_ITEM7_P213_S3	The most significant financial statement impact of a decrease in the estimated useful lives of Occidental's chemical plants would be on depreciation expense.
797468_18_ITEM7_P213_S4	For example, a reduction in the remaining useful lives of one year would increase depreciation and reduce pre-tax earnings by approximately $44 million per year.
797468_18_ITEM7_P214_S0	Midstream, Marketing and Other Assets Derivatives are carried at fair value and on a net basis when a legal right of offset exists with the same counterparty.
797468_18_ITEM7_P215_S0	Occidental applies hedge accounting when transactions meet specified criteria for cash-flow hedge treatment and management elects and documents such treatment.
797468_18_ITEM7_P215_S1	Otherwise, any fair value gains or losses are recognized in earnings in the current period.
797468_18_ITEM7_P216_S0	For cash-flow hedges, the gain or loss on the effective portion of the derivative is reported as a component of other comprehensive income (OCI) with an offsetting adjustment to the basis of the item being hedged.
797468_18_ITEM7_P216_S1	Realized gains or losses from cash-flow hedges, and any ineffective portion, are recorded as a component of net sales in the consolidated statements of operations.
797468_18_ITEM7_P217_S0	Ineffectiveness is primarily created by a lack of correlation between the hedged item and the hedging instrument due to location, quality, grade or changes in the expected quantity of the hedged item.
797468_18_ITEM7_P218_S0	Gains and losses from derivative instruments are reported net in the consolidated statements of operations.
797468_18_ITEM7_P218_S1	There were no fair value hedges as of and during the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015.
797468_18_ITEM7_P219_S0	throughout its life, it is expected that changes in the fair value or cash flows of the hedged item will be offset by 80 to 125 percent of the changes in the fair value or cash flows, respectively, of the hedging instrument.
797468_18_ITEM7_P220_S0	In the case of hedging a forecast transaction, the transaction must be probable and must present an exposure to variations in cash flows that could ultimately affect reported net income or loss.
797468_18_ITEM7_P220_S1	Occidental discontinues hedge accounting when it determines that a derivative has ceased to be highly effective as a hedge; when the hedged item matures or is sold or repaid; or when a forecast transaction is no longer deemed probable.
797468_18_ITEM7_P221_S0	Occidental's midstream and marketing PP E is depreciated over the estimated useful lives of the assets, using either the unit-of-production or straight-line method.
797468_18_ITEM7_P222_S0	Occidental performs impairment tests on its midstream and marketing assets whenever events or changes in circumstances lead to a reduction in the estimated useful lives or estimated future cash flows that would indicate that the carrying amount may not be recoverable, or when management s plans change with respect to those assets.
797468_18_ITEM7_P222_S1	Any impairment loss would be calculated as the excess of the asset's net book value over its estimated fair value.
797468_18_ITEM7_P223_S0	Fair Value Measurements Occidental has categorized its assets and liabilities that are measured at fair value in a three-level fair value hierarchy, based on the inputs to the valuation techniques: Level 1 using quoted prices in active markets for the assets or liabilities; Level 2 using observable inputs other than quoted prices for the assets or liabilities; and Level 3 using unobservable inputs.
797468_18_ITEM7_P223_S1	Transfers between levels, if any, are recognized at the end of each reporting period.
797468_18_ITEM7_P224_S0	Fair Values - Recurring Occidental primarily applies the market approach for recurring fair value measurements, maximizes its use of observable inputs and minimizes its use of unobservable inputs.
797468_18_ITEM7_P224_S1	Occidental utilizes the mid-point between bid and ask prices for valuing the majority of its assets and liabilities measured and reported at fair value.
797468_18_ITEM7_P224_S2	In addition to using market data, Occidental makes assumptions in valuing its assets and liabilities, including assumptions about the risks inherent in the inputs to the valuation technique.
797468_18_ITEM7_P224_S3	For assets and liabilities carried at fair value, Occidental measures fair value using the following methods:
797468_18_ITEM7_P225_S0	Occidental values exchange-cleared commodity derivatives using closing prices provided by the exchange as of the balance sheet date.
797468_18_ITEM7_P225_S1	These derivatives are classified as Level 1.
797468_18_ITEM7_P226_S0	Over-the-Counter (OTC) bilateral financial commodity contracts, foreign exchange contracts, options and physical commodity forward purchase and sale contracts are generally classified as Level 2 and are generally valued using quotations provided by brokers or industry-standard models that consider various inputs, including quoted forward prices for commodities, time value, volatility factors, credit risk and current market and contractual prices for the underlying instruments, as well as other relevant economic measures.
797468_18_ITEM7_P227_S0	are observable in the marketplace throughout the full term of the instrument, and can be derived from observable data or are supported by observable prices at which transactions are executed in the marketplace.
797468_18_ITEM7_P228_S0	Occidental values commodity derivatives based on a market approach that considers various assumptions, including quoted forward commodity prices and market yield curves.
797468_18_ITEM7_P228_S1	The assumptions used include inputs that are generally unobservable in the marketplace or are observable but have been adjusted based upon various assumptions and the fair value is designated as Level 3 within the valuation hierarchy.
797468_18_ITEM7_P229_S0	Occidental generally uses an income approach to measure fair value when there is not a market-observable price for an identical or similar asset or liability.
797468_18_ITEM7_P229_S1	This approach utilizes management's judgments regarding expectations of projected cash flows, and discounts those cash flows using a risk-adjusted discount rate.
797468_18_ITEM7_P230_S0	Environmental Liabilities and Expenditures Environmental expenditures that relate to current operations are expensed or capitalized as appropriate.
797468_18_ITEM7_P230_S1	Occidental records environmental reserves and related charges and expenses for estimated remediation costs that relate to existing conditions from past operations when environmental remediation efforts are probable and the costs can be reasonably estimated.
797468_18_ITEM7_P230_S2	In determining the reserves and the range of reasonably possible additional losses, Occidental refers to currently available information, including relevant past experience, remedial objectives, available technologies, applicable laws and regulations and cost-sharing arrangements.
797468_18_ITEM7_P230_S3	Occidental bases environmental reserves on management s estimate of the most likely cost to be incurred, using the most cost-effective technology reasonably expected to achieve the remedial objective.
797468_18_ITEM7_P230_S4	Occidental periodically reviews reserves and adjusts them as new information becomes available.
797468_18_ITEM7_P230_S5	Occidental records environmental reserves on a discounted basis when it deems the aggregate amount and timing of cash payments to be reliably determinable at the time the reserves are established.
797468_18_ITEM7_P230_S6	The reserve methodology with respect to discounting for a specific site is not modified once it is established.
797468_18_ITEM7_P230_S7	Presently none of the environmental reserves are recorded on a discounted basis.
797468_18_ITEM7_P231_S0	Occidental generally records reimbursements or recoveries of environmental remediation costs in income when received, or when receipt of recovery is highly probable.
797468_18_ITEM7_P231_S1	Many factors could affect Occidental s future remediation costs and result in adjustments to its environmental reserves and range of reasonably possible additional losses.
797468_18_ITEM7_P232_S0	change remediation requirements or affect cost sharing or allocation of liability; and (6) changes in allocation or cost-sharing arrangements may occur.
797468_18_ITEM7_P232_S1	Certain sites involve multiple parties with various cost-sharing arrangements, which fall into the following three categories: (1) environmental proceedings that result in a negotiated or prescribed allocation of remediation costs among Occidental and other alleged potentially responsible parties; (2) oil and gas ventures in which each participant pays its proportionate share of remediation costs reflecting its working interest; or (3) contractual arrangements, typically relating to purchases and sales of properties, in which the parties to the transaction agree to methods of allocating remediation costs.
797468_18_ITEM7_P232_S2	In these circumstances, Occidental evaluates the financial viability of other parties with whom it is alleged to be jointly liable, the degree of their commitment to participate and the consequences to Occidental of their failure to participate when estimating Occidental's ultimate share of liability.
797468_18_ITEM7_P232_S3	Occidental records reserves at its expected net cost of remedial activities and, based on these factors, believes that it will not be required to assume a share of liability of such other potentially responsible parties in an amount materially above amounts reserved.
797468_18_ITEM7_P232_S4	In addition to the costs of investigations and cleanup measures, which often take in excess of 10 years at NPL sites, Occidental's reserves include management's estimates of the costs to operate and maintain remedial systems.
797468_18_ITEM7_P232_S5	If remedial systems are modified over time in response to significant changes in site-specific data, laws, regulations, technologies or engineering estimates, Occidental reviews and adjusts its reserves accordingly.
797468_18_ITEM7_P233_S0	If Occidental were to adjust the environmental reserve balance based on the factors described above, the amount of the increase or decrease would be recognized in earnings.
797468_18_ITEM7_P233_S1	For example, if the reserve balance were reduced by 10 percent, Occidental would record a pre-tax gain of $87 million.
797468_18_ITEM7_P233_S2	If the reserve balance were increased by 10 percent, Occidental would record an additional remediation expense of $87 million.
797468_18_ITEM7_P234_S0	Other Loss Contingencies Occidental is involved, in the normal course of business, in lawsuits, claims and other legal proceedings and audits.
797468_18_ITEM7_P234_S1	Occidental accrues reserves for these matters when it is probable that a liability has been incurred and the liability can be reasonably estimated.
797468_18_ITEM7_P234_S2	In addition, Occidental discloses, in aggregate, its exposure to loss in excess of the amount recorded on the balance sheet for these matters if it is reasonably possible that an additional material loss may be incurred.
797468_18_ITEM7_P234_S3	Occidental reviews its loss contingencies on an ongoing basis.
797468_18_ITEM7_P234_S4	Loss contingencies are based on judgments made by management with respect to the likely outcome of these matters and are adjusted as appropriate.
797468_18_ITEM7_P234_S5	Management s judgments could change based on new information, changes in, or interpretations of, laws or regulations, changes in management s plans or intentions, opinions regarding the outcome of legal proceedings, or other factors.
797468_18_ITEM7_P234_S6	See "Lawsuits, Claims and Contingencies" for additional information.
797468_18_ITEM7_P235_S0	See Note 3 in the Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements in Part II Item 8 of this Form 10-K.

797468_18_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Commodity Price Risk General Occidental s results are sensitive to fluctuations in oil, NGLs and natural gas prices.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P0_S1	Price changes at current global prices and levels of production affect Occidental s pre-tax annual income by approximately $110 million for a $1 per barrel change in oil prices and $30 million for a $1 per barrel change in NGLs prices.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P0_S2	If domestic natural gas prices varied by $0.50 per Mcf, it would have an estimated annual effect on Occidental's pre-tax income of approximately $20 million.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P0_S3	These price-change sensitivities include the impact of PSC and similar contract volume changes on income.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P0_S4	If production levels change in the future, the sensitivity of Occidental s results to prices also will change.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P0_S5	Marketing results are sensitive to price changes of oil, natural gas and, to a lesser degree, other commodities.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P0_S6	These sensitivities are additionally dependent on marketing volumes and cannot be predicted reliably.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P0_S7	Occidental s results are also sensitive to fluctuations in chemical prices.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P0_S8	A variation in chlorine and caustic soda prices of $10 per ton would have a pre-tax annual effect on income of approximately $10 million and $30 million, respectively.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P0_S9	A variation in PVC prices of $0.01 per lb.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P1_S0	have a pre-tax annual effect on income of approximately $30 million.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P2_S0	Historically, over time, product price changes have tracked raw material and feedstock product price changes, somewhat mitigating the effect of price changes on margins.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P3_S0	According to IHS Chemical or Townsend, 2017 average contract prices were: chlorine-$324 per ton; caustic soda-$635 per ton; and PVC-$0.40 per lb.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P4_S0	Occidental uses derivative instruments, including a combination of short-term futures, forwards, options and swaps, to obtain the average prices for the relevant production month and to improve realized prices for oil and gas.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P5_S0	Risk Management Occidental conducts its risk management activities for marketing and trading under the controls and governance of its risk control policies.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P5_S1	The controls under these policies are implemented and enforced by a risk management group which monitors risk by providing an independent and separate evaluation and check.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P5_S2	Members of the risk management group report to the Corporate Vice President and Treasurer.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P5_S3	Controls for these activities include limits on value at risk, limits on credit, limits on total notional trade value, segregation of duties, delegation of authority, daily price verifications, reporting to senior management of various risk measures and a number of other policy and procedural controls.

797468_18_ITEM7A_P15_S0	Credit Risk The majority of Occidental's counterparty credit risk is related to the physical delivery of energy commodities to its customers and their inability to meet their settlement commitments.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P15_S1	Occidental manages credit risk by selecting counterparties that it believes to be financially strong, by entering into netting arrangements with counterparties and by requiring collateral or other credit risk mitigants, as appropriate.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P15_S2	Occidental actively evaluates the creditworthiness of its counterparties, assigns appropriate credit limits, and monitors credit exposures against those assigned limits.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P15_S3	Occidental also enters into future contracts through regulated exchanges with select clearinghouses and brokers, which are subject to minimal credit risk as a significant portion of these transactions settle on a daily margin basis.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P15_S4	Certain of Occidental's OTC derivative instruments contain credit-risk-contingent features, primarily tied to credit ratings for Occidental or its counterparties, which may affect the amount of collateral that each would need to post.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P15_S5	Occidental believes that if it had received a one-notch reduction in its credit ratings, it would not have resulted in a material change in its collateral-posting requirements as of December 31, 2017 and 2016 .
797468_18_ITEM7A_P15_S6	As of December 31, 2017 , the substantial majority of the credit exposures were with investment grade counterparties.
797468_18_ITEM7A_P15_S7	Occidental believes its exposure to credit-related losses at December 31, 2017 was not material and losses associated with credit risk have been insignificant for all years presented.

797468_18_ITEM8_P4_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
797468_18_ITEM8_P4_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
797468_18_ITEM8_P4_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
797468_18_ITEM8_P4_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.

797468_18_ITEM8_P10_S0	NATURE OF OPERATIONS In this report, "Occidental" means Occidental Petroleum Corporation, a Delaware corporation (OPC), or OPC and one or more entities in which it owns a controlling interest (subsidiaries).
797468_18_ITEM8_P11_S0	Occidental conducts its operations through various subsidiaries and affiliates.
797468_18_ITEM8_P11_S1	Occidental's principal businesses consist of three segments.
797468_18_ITEM8_P12_S0	The oil and gas segment explores for, develops and produces oil and condensate, natural gas liquids (NGLs) and natural gas.
797468_18_ITEM8_P12_S1	The chemical segment (OxyChem) mainly manufactures and markets basic chemicals and vinyls.
797468_18_ITEM8_P13_S0	The midstream and marketing segment gathers, processes, transports, stores, purchases and markets oil, condensate, NGLs, natural gas, carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) and power.
797468_18_ITEM8_P13_S1	It also trades around its assets, including transportation and storage capacity.
797468_18_ITEM8_P13_S2	Additionally, the midstream and marketing segment operates a crude oil export terminal, as well as invests in entities that conduct similar activities.
797468_18_ITEM8_P14_S0	The consolidated financial statements have been prepared in conformity with United States generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) and include the accounts of OPC, its subsidiaries and its undivided interests in oil and gas exploration and production ventures.
797468_18_ITEM8_P15_S0	Occidental accounts for its share of oil and gas exploration and production ventures, in which it has a direct working interest, by reporting its proportionate share of assets, liabilities, revenues, costs and cash flows within the relevant lines on the balance sheets, income statements and cash flow statements.
797468_18_ITEM8_P15_S1	Certain financial statements, notes and supplementary data for prior years have been reclassified to conform to the 2017 presentation.
797468_18_ITEM8_P16_S0	INVESTMENTS IN UNCONSOLIDATED ENTITIES Occidental s percentage interest in the underlying net assets of affiliates as to which it exercises significant influence without having a controlling interest (excluding oil and gas ventures in which Occidental holds an undivided interest) are accounted for under the equity method.
797468_18_ITEM8_P16_S1	Occidental reviews equity-method investments for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that an other-than-temporary decline in value may have occurred.
797468_18_ITEM8_P16_S2	The amount of impairment, if any, is based on quoted market prices, when available, or other valuation techniques, including discounted cash flows.
797468_18_ITEM8_P17_S0	REVENUE RECOGNITION Revenue is recognized from oil and gas production when title has passed to the customer, which occurs when the product is shipped.
797468_18_ITEM8_P17_S1	Where oil is shipped by tanker, title passes when the tanker is loaded or product is received by the customer, depending on the shipping terms.
797468_18_ITEM8_P17_S2	This process occasionally causes a difference between actual production in a reporting period and sales volumes that have been recognized as revenue.
797468_18_ITEM8_P17_S3	Revenues from the production of oil and gas properties in which Occidental has an interest with other producers are recognized on the basis of Occidental s net revenue interest.
797468_18_ITEM8_P17_S4	Revenue from chemical product sales is recognized when the product is shipped and title has passed to the customer.
797468_18_ITEM8_P18_S0	Certain incentive programs may provide for payments or credits to be made to customers based on the volume of product purchased over a defined period.
797468_18_ITEM8_P18_S1	Total customer incentive payments over a given period are estimated and recorded as a reduction to revenue ratably over the contract period.
797468_18_ITEM8_P18_S2	Such estimates are evaluated and revised as warranted.
797468_18_ITEM8_P19_S0	Revenue from marketing activities is recognized on net settled transactions upon completion of contract terms and, for physical deliveries, upon title transfer.
797468_18_ITEM8_P19_S1	For unsettled transactions, contracts are recorded at fair value and changes in fair value are reflected in net sales.
797468_18_ITEM8_P20_S0	Revenue from all marketing activities is reported on a net basis.
797468_18_ITEM8_P20_S1	Occidental records revenue net of any taxes, such as sales taxes, that are assessed by governmental authorities on Occidental's customers.
797468_18_ITEM8_P21_S0	RISKS AND UNCERTAINTIES The process of preparing consolidated financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires Occidental's management to make informed estimates and judgments regarding certain types of financial statement balances and disclosures.
797468_18_ITEM8_P21_S1	Such estimates primarily relate to unsettled transactions and events as of the date of the consolidated financial statements and judgments on expected outcomes as well as the materiality of transactions and balances.
797468_18_ITEM8_P21_S2	Changes in facts and circumstances or discovery of new information relating to such transactions and events may result in revised estimates and judgments and actual results may differ from estimates upon settlement.
797468_18_ITEM8_P21_S3	Management believes that these estimates and judgments provide a reasonable basis for the fair presentation of Occidental s financial statements.
797468_18_ITEM8_P22_S0	Occidental establishes a valuation allowance against net operating losses and other deferred tax assets to the extent it believes the future benefit from these assets will not be realized in the statutory carryforward periods.
797468_18_ITEM8_P22_S1	Realization of deferred tax assets is dependent upon Occidental generating sufficient future taxable income and reversal of temporary differences in jurisdictions where such assets originate.
797468_18_ITEM8_P23_S0	The accompanying consolidated financial statements include assets of approximately $9.8 billion as of December 31, 2017 , and net sales of approximately $4.4 billion for the year ended December 31, 2017 , relating to Occidental s operations in countries outside North America.
797468_18_ITEM8_P24_S0	Occidental operates some of its oil and gas business in countries that have experienced political instability, nationalizations, corruption, armed conflict, terrorism, insurgency, civil unrest, security problems, labor unrest, OPEC production restrictions, equipment import restrictions and sanctions, all of which increase Occidental's risk of loss, delayed or restricted production or may result in other adverse consequences.
797468_18_ITEM8_P24_S1	Occidental attempts to conduct its affairs so as to mitigate its exposure to such risks and would seek compensation in the event of nationalization.
797468_18_ITEM8_P25_S0	Because Occidental s major products are commodities, significant changes in the prices of oil and gas and chemical products may have a significant impact on Occidental s results of operations.
797468_18_ITEM8_P25_S1	Also, see "Property, Plant and Equipment" below.

797468_18_ITEM8_P28_S0	INVESTMENTS Available-for-sale securities are recorded at fair value with any unrealized gains or losses included in accumulated other comprehensive income/loss (AOCI).
797468_18_ITEM8_P28_S1	Trading securities are recorded at fair value with unrealized and realized gains or losses included in net sales.
797468_18_ITEM8_P28_S2	A decline in market value of any available-for-sale securities below cost that is deemed to be other-than-temporary results in an impairment to reduce the carrying amount to fair value.
797468_18_ITEM8_P28_S3	To determine whether an impairment is other-than-temporary, Occidental considers all available information relevant to the investment, including past events and current conditions.
797468_18_ITEM8_P28_S4	Evidence considered in this assessment includes the reasons for the impairment, the severity and duration of the impairment, changes in value subsequent to year end, and the general market condition in the geographic area or industry the investee operates in.
797468_18_ITEM8_P29_S0	INVENTORIES Materials and supplies are valued at weighted-average cost and are reviewed periodically for obsolescence.
797468_18_ITEM8_P29_S1	Oil, NGLs and natural gas inventories are valued at the lower of cost or market.
797468_18_ITEM8_P29_S2	For the chemical segment, Occidental's finished goods inventories are valued at the lower of cost or market.
797468_18_ITEM8_P29_S3	For most of its domestic inventories, other than materials and supplies, the chemical segment uses the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method as it better matches current costs and current revenue.
797468_18_ITEM8_P29_S4	For other countries, Occidental uses the first-in, first-out method (if the costs of goods are specifically identifiable) or the average-cost method (if the costs of goods are not specifically identifiable).
797468_18_ITEM8_P30_S0	The carrying value of Occidental s property, plant and equipment (PP E) represents the cost incurred to acquire or develop the asset, including any asset retirement obligations and capitalized interest, net of accumulated depreciation, depletion and amortization (DD A) and any impairment charges.
797468_18_ITEM8_P30_S1	For assets acquired, PP E cost is based on fair values at the acquisition date.
797468_18_ITEM8_P31_S0	Asset retirement obligations and interest costs incurred in connection with qualifying capital expenditures are capitalized and amortized over the lives of the related assets.
797468_18_ITEM8_P32_S0	Occidental uses the successful efforts method to account for its oil and gas properties.
797468_18_ITEM8_P32_S1	Under this method, Occidental capitalizes costs of acquiring properties, costs of drilling successful exploration wells and development costs.
797468_18_ITEM8_P32_S2	The costs of exploratory wells are initially capitalized pending a determination of whether proved reserves have been found.
797468_18_ITEM8_P32_S3	If proved reserves have been found, the costs of exploratory wells remain capitalized.
797468_18_ITEM8_P32_S4	Otherwise, Occidental charges the costs of the related wells to expense.
797468_18_ITEM8_P33_S0	In some cases, a determination of proved reserves cannot be made at the completion of drilling, requiring additional testing and evaluation of the wells.
797468_18_ITEM8_P33_S1	Occidental generally expenses the costs of such exploratory wells if a determination of proved reserves has not been made within a 12 -month period after drilling is complete.
797468_18_ITEM8_P33_S2	The following table summarizes the activity of capitalized exploratory well costs for continuing operations for the years ended December 31:
797468_18_ITEM8_P34_S0	Occidental expenses annual lease rentals, the costs of injectants used in production and geological, geophysical and seismic costs as incurred.
797468_18_ITEM8_P35_S0	Occidental determines depreciation and depletion of oil and gas producing properties by the unit-of-production method.
797468_18_ITEM8_P35_S1	It amortizes leasehold costs over total proved reserves, and capitalized development and successful exploration costs over proved developed reserves.
797468_18_ITEM8_P36_S0	Proved oil and gas reserves are those quantities of oil and gas which, by analysis of geoscience and engineering data, can be estimated with reasonable certainty to be economically producible from a given date forward, from known reservoirs, and under existing economic conditions, operating methods, and government regulations prior to the time at which contracts providing the right to operate expire, unless evidence indicates that renewal is reasonably certain, regardless of whether deterministic or probabilistic methods are used for the estimation.
797468_18_ITEM8_P36_S1	Occidental has no proved oil and gas reserves for which the determination of economic producibility is subject to the completion of major additional capital expenditures.
797468_18_ITEM8_P37_S0	Occidental performs impairment tests with respect to its proved properties whenever events or circumstances indicate that the carrying value of property may not be recoverable.
797468_18_ITEM8_P37_S1	If there is an indication the carrying amount of the asset may not be recovered due to declines in current and forward prices, significant changes in reserve estimates, changes in management's plans, or other significant events, management will evaluate the property for impairment.
797468_18_ITEM8_P37_S2	Under the successful efforts method, if the sum of the undiscounted cash flows is less than the carrying value of the proved property, the carrying value is reduced to estimated fair value and reported as an impairment charge in the period.
797468_18_ITEM8_P38_S0	Individual proved properties are grouped for impairment purposes at the lowest level for which there are identifiable cash flows.
797468_18_ITEM8_P38_S1	The fair value of impaired assets is typically determined based on the present value of expected future cash flows using discount rates believed to be consistent with those used by market participants.
797468_18_ITEM8_P39_S0	The impairment test incorporates a number of assumptions involving expectations of future cash flows which can change significantly over time.
797468_18_ITEM8_P39_S1	These assumptions include estimates of future product prices, contractual prices, estimates of risk-adjusted oil and gas reserves and estimates of future operating and development costs.
797468_18_ITEM8_P39_S2	See Note 15 and below for further discussion of asset impairments.
797468_18_ITEM8_P40_S0	A portion of the carrying value of Occidental s oil and gas properties is attributable to unproved properties.
797468_18_ITEM8_P40_S1	Net capitalized costs attributable to unproved properties were $1.0 billion and $1.4 billion at December 31, 2017 , and 2016 , respectively.
797468_18_ITEM8_P40_S2	The unproved amounts are not subject to DD A until they are classified as proved properties.
797468_18_ITEM8_P40_S3	Capitalized costs attributable to the properties become subject to DD A when proved reserves are assigned to the property.
797468_18_ITEM8_P40_S4	If the exploration efforts are unsuccessful, or management decides not to pursue development of these properties as a result of lower commodity prices, higher development and operating costs, contractual conditions or other factors, the capitalized costs of the related properties would be expensed.
797468_18_ITEM8_P40_S5	The timing of any writedowns of these unproved properties, if warranted, depends upon management's plans, the nature, timing and extent of future exploration and development activities and their results.
797468_18_ITEM8_P41_S0	Chemical Occidental s chemical assets are depreciated using either the unit-of-production or the straight-line method, based upon the estimated useful lives of the facilities.
797468_18_ITEM8_P41_S1	The estimated useful lives of Occidental s chemical assets, which range from three years to fifty years, are also used for impairment tests.
797468_18_ITEM8_P41_S2	The estimated useful lives for the chemical facilities are based on the assumption that Occidental will provide an appropriate level of annual expenditures to ensure productive capacity is sustained.
797468_18_ITEM8_P41_S3	Such expenditures consist of ongoing routine repairs and maintenance, as well as planned major maintenance activities (PMMA).
797468_18_ITEM8_P41_S4	Ongoing routine repairs and maintenance expenditures are expensed as incurred.
797468_18_ITEM8_P41_S5	PMMA costs are capitalized and amortized over the period until the next planned overhaul.
797468_18_ITEM8_P41_S6	Additionally, Occidental incurs capital expenditures that extend the remaining useful lives of existing assets, increase their capacity or operating efficiency beyond the original specification or add value through modification for a different use.
797468_18_ITEM8_P41_S7	These capital expenditures are not considered in the initial determination of the useful lives of these assets at the time they are placed into service.
797468_18_ITEM8_P41_S8	The resulting revision, if any, of the asset s estimated useful life is measured and accounted for prospectively.
797468_18_ITEM8_P41_S9	Without these continued expenditures, the useful lives of these assets could decrease significantly.
797468_18_ITEM8_P41_S10	Other factors that could change the estimated useful lives of Occidental s chemical assets include sustained higher or lower product prices, which are particularly affected by both domestic and foreign competition, demand, feedstock costs, energy prices, environmental regulations and technological changes.
797468_18_ITEM8_P42_S0	Occidental performs impairment tests on its chemical assets whenever events or changes in circumstances lead to a reduction in the estimated useful lives or estimated future cash flows that would indicate that the carrying amount may not be recoverable, or when management s plans change with respect to those assets.
797468_18_ITEM8_P42_S1	Any impairment loss would be calculated as the excess of the asset s net book value over its estimated fair value.
797468_18_ITEM8_P43_S0	Midstream and Marketing Occidental s midstream and marketing PP E is depreciated over the estimated useful lives of the assets, using either the unit-of-production or straight-line method.
797468_18_ITEM8_P43_S1	Occidental performs impairment tests on its midstream and marketing assets whenever events or changes in circumstances lead to a reduction in the estimated useful lives or estimated future cash flows that would indicate that the carrying amount may not be recoverable, or when management s plans change with respect to those assets.
797468_18_ITEM8_P43_S2	Any impairment loss would be calculated as the excess of the asset s net book value over its estimated fair value.
